verses.latin: Fuit vir unus de Ramathaim Sophim de monte Ephraim, et nomen ejus Elcana, filius Jeroham, filii Eliu, filii Thohu, filii Suph, Ephratæus.
verses.english: There was a certain man from Ramathaim Sophim, from the mountain region of Ephraim. His name was Elcana, a son of Jeroham, who was a son of Eliu, who was a son of Thohu, who was a son of Suph—he was an Ephratite.

verses.latin: Et habuit duas uxores: nomen uni Anna, et nomen secundæ Phenenna. Fueruntque Phenennæ filii: Annæ autem non erant liberi.
verses.english: He had two wives: the name of one was Anna, and the name of the second was Phenenna. Phenenna had children, but Anna had no children.

verses.latin: Et ascendebat vir ille de civitate sua in diebus statutis, ut adoraret, et sacrificaret Domino exercituum in Silo. Erant autem ibi duo filii Heli, Ophni et Phinees, sacerdotes Domini.
verses.english: And this man would go up from his city at the appointed times each year to worship and sacrifice to the Lord of hosts in Silo. Heli’s two sons, Ophni and Phinees, were serving there as priests of the Lord.

verses.latin: Venibat ergo dies, et immolabat Elcana, dabatque Phenennæ uxori suæ, et cunctis filiis ejus et filiabus, partes.
verses.english: Whenever the day came for the sacrifice, Elcana would make his offering. He would give portions to his wife Phenenna, and to all her sons and daughters.

verses.latin: Annæ autem dedit partem unam tristis: eo quod Anna non haberet liberos. Et Dominus concluserat os ejus.
verses.english: But to Anna, he gave only one portion, and he was sorrowful, for Anna had no children. The Lord had closed her womb, so she could not conceive.

verses.latin: Affligebat quoque eam æmula ejus, et vehementer perturbabat, in tantum ut exprobraret, quod Dominus occlusisset vulvam illius.
verses.english: Her rival wife, Phenenna, also tormented her and greatly distressed her, constantly taunting Anna over the fact that the Lord had closed her womb.

verses.latin: Sicque faciebat per singulos annos cum ascenderent templum Domini: et provocabat eam: porro illa flebat, et non cibabatur.
verses.english: And she did this year after year, whenever they went up to the temple of the Lord. Phenenna would provoke Anna, and Anna would weep and refuse to eat.

verses.latin: Dixit ergo ei Elcana vir suus: Anna, cur fles? et quare non comedis? et cur mæsto es corde? numquid non ego melior sum tibi quam decem filii?
verses.english: Then Elcana, her husband, said to her: “Anna, why are you weeping? And why are you not eating? And why is your heart so sad? Am I not better to you than ten sons would be?”

verses.latin: Surrexit ergo Anna postquam comederat et biberat in Silo: et Heli sacerdos sedebat super sellam ante postes templi Domini.
verses.english: So Anna rose up after they had eaten and drunk in Silo. Heli the priest was sitting on a seat by the doorposts of the Lord’s temple.

verses.latin: Et Anna cum esset amaro animo, oravit Dominum, flens largiter.
verses.english: Anna was in deep bitterness of soul. She prayed to the Lord, weeping profusely.

verses.latin: Et votum vovit, dicens: Domine exercituum, si respiciens videris afflictionem ancillæ tuæ, et memor fueris mei, et non oblitus fueris ancillæ tuæ, et dederis ancillæ tuæ sexum virilem: dabo eum Domino omnibus diebus vitæ ejus, et novacula non ascendet super caput ejus.
verses.english: And she made a solemn vow, saying: “Lord of hosts, if You would only look upon the affliction of your handmaid, and remember me, and not forget your handmaid, and grant your handmaid a male child, then I will give him to the Lord for all the days of his life. And no razor will ever come upon his head—meaning he will be dedicated to You as a Nazirite.”

verses.latin: Factum est autem cum illa multiplicaret preces coram Domino, ut Heli observaret os ejus.
verses.english: It so happened that as she continued to multiply her prayers before the Lord, Heli observed her mouth.

verses.latin: Porro Anna loquebatur in corde suo, tantumque labia ejus movebantur, vox autem ejus non audiebatur: putavit ergo Heli eam ebriam.
verses.english: Now, Anna was speaking in her heart; only her lips were moving, but her voice could not be heard. So Heli thought she was drunk.

verses.latin: Dixitque ei: Usquequo ebria eris? digere paulisper vinum, quo mades.
verses.english: And he said to her: “How long will you be drunk? Sober up from your wine for a little while, which has made you intoxicated.”

verses.latin: Respondens Anna, ait: Non, domine mi, mulier misera spiritu ego sum: et vinum et omne quod inebriare potest non bibi, sed effudi animam meam coram Domino.
verses.english: Anna answered and said: “No, my lord, I am a woman with a deeply troubled spirit. I have drunk neither wine nor anything that could make me drunk; instead, I have poured out my very soul before the Lord.”

verses.latin: Ne reputes ancillam tuam quasi unam de filiabus Belial: quoniam ex abundantia doloris et mæroris mei locuta sum usque nunc.
verses.english: Do not consider your handmaid to be one of the daughters of Belial—a worthless or wicked woman. For it is out of the abundance of my great sorrow and grief that I have spoken until now.”

verses.latin: Respondit ergo Heli, et dixit: Vade in pace: et Deus Israël det tibi petitionem tuam, quam rogasti ab eo.
verses.english: Then Heli answered and said: “Go in peace. And may the God of Israel grant you your petition, which you have asked from Him.”

verses.latin: Quæ ait: Inveniat ancilla tua gratiam in oculis tuis. Et abiit mulier in viam suam, et comedit, et vultus ejus non sunt amplius in diversa mutati.
verses.english: And she said: “May your handmaid find favor in your eyes.” Then the woman went on her way, and she ate, and her countenance was no longer downcast or troubled.

verses.latin: Et surrexerunt mane, et adoraverunt coram Domino: reversique sunt, et venerunt in domum suam Ramatha. Cognovit autem Elcana uxorem suam Annam, et Dominus recordatus est ejus.
verses.english: They rose up early in the morning and worshipped before the Lord. Then they returned and came to their home in Ramatha. And Elcana knew Anna his wife, and the Lord remembered her by granting her request.

verses.latin: Et factum est post circulum dierum, concepit Anna, et peperit filium, vocavitque nomen ejus Samuel, eo quod de Domino postulasset eum.
verses.english: And so it was that after the passage of some days, Anna conceived and gave birth to a son. She named him Samuel, because she had asked for him from the Lord.

verses.latin: Et ascendit vir Elcana, et omnis domus ejus, ut immolaret Domino hostiam annuam, et votum suum.
verses.english: Then Elcana, along with all his household, went up to offer to the Lord his annual sacrifice and his solemn vow.

verses.latin: Anna autem non ascendit: sed dixit marito suo: Non vadam donec ablactetur puer, et ducam illum, et appareat ante conspectum Domini, et maneat ibi jugiter.
verses.english: But Anna did not go up. Instead, she said to her husband: “I will not go until the child is weaned. Then I will bring him, and he will appear before the presence of the Lord, and he will remain there permanently.”

verses.latin: Dixitque ei Elcana vir suus: Fac quod bonum tibi videtur, et mane hic, donec ablactes eum: tantum ut impleat Dominus verbum suum. Mansit ergo mulier, et lactavit filium suum, donec ablactaret eum.
verses.english: And Elcana, her husband, said to her: “Do what seems good to you. Stay here until you wean him, provided only that the Lord may fulfill His word concerning the child’s dedication.” So the woman stayed and nursed her son until she weaned him.

verses.latin: Et adduxit eum secum postquam ablactaverat, cum tribus vitulis, et tribus modiis farinæ, et amphora vini, et adduxit ad domum Domini in Silo. Puer autem adhuc erat infantulus.
verses.english: And after she had weaned him, she brought him up with her, along with three young bullocks, three measures of flour, and a jar of wine. She brought him to the house of the Lord in Silo. The boy was still very young.

verses.latin: Et immolaverunt vitulum, et obtulerunt puerum Heli.
verses.english: And they sacrificed a bullock, and they brought the boy to Heli.

verses.latin: Et dixit Anna: Obsecro, domine mi, vivit anima tua, domine mi: ego sum illa mulier, quæ steti coram te hic orans Dominum.
verses.english: And Anna said: “I beg you, my lord, as your soul lives, my lord—I am that very woman who stood here before you, praying to the Lord.”

verses.latin: Pro hoc puero oravi, et dedit mihi Dominus petitionem meam, quam postulavi ab eo.
verses.english: “It was for this very boy that I prayed, and the Lord has granted me my petition which I asked from Him.”

verses.latin: Idcirco et ego commodavi eum Domino cunctis diebus vitæ ejus, ut maneat commissus Domino. Et adoraverunt ibi Dominum.
verses.english: “Therefore, I have also entrusted him to the Lord for all the days of his life, that he may remain dedicated to the Lord.” And they worshipped the Lord there.

verses.latin: Fuit vir unus de Ramathaim Sophim, de monte Ephraim, et nomen ejus Elcana, filius Jeroham, filii Eliu, filii Thohu, filii Suph, Ephratæus:
verses.english: There was a man from Ramathaim-Zophim, in the hill country of Ephraim. His name was Elcana, and he was the son of Jeroham, son of Eliu, son of Thohu, son of Suph, an Ephraimite.

verses.latin: Et habuit duas uxores: nomen uni Anna, et nomen secundæ Phenenna. Fueruntque Phenennæ filii: Annæ autem non erant liberi.
verses.english: He had two wives: one was named Anna, and the other Phenenna. Phenenna had children, but Anna had no children.

verses.latin: Ascendebat vir ille de civitate sua in diebus statutis, ut adoraret et sacrificaret Domino exercituum in Silo. Erant autem ibi duo filii Heli, Ophni et Phinees, sacerdotes Domini.
verses.english: That man would go up from his city each year at the appointed times to worship and offer sacrifice to the Lord of hosts in Silo. Now, the two sons of Eli, Ophni and Phinees, were serving there as priests of the Lord.

verses.latin: Venit ergo dies, et immolavit Elcana, deditque Phenennæ uxori suæ, et cunctis filiis ejus et filiabus, partes:
verses.english: So when the day came for Elcana to offer the sacrifice, he gave portions of the meat to Phenenna, his wife, and to all her sons and daughters.

verses.latin: Annæ autem dedit partem unam tristis, quia Annæ non erat filius: et Dominus concluserat os ejus.
verses.english: But to Anna, he gave a special portion, though his heart was heavy, because Anna had no son, for the Lord had closed her womb.

verses.latin: Affligebat quoque eam æmula ejus, et vehementer perturbabat, pro eo quod concluserat Dominus os ejus.
verses.english: Her rival, Phenenna, also tormented and greatly distressed her constantly because the Lord had closed Anna's womb and she had no children.

verses.latin: Sicque faciebat per singulos annos: cum ascenderent templum Domini, sic provocabat eam. Itaque flebat, et non cibabatur.
verses.english: This continued year after year; whenever they went up to the house of the Lord, Phenenna would provoke her. So Anna would weep and refuse to eat anything.

verses.latin: Dixit ergo ei Elcana vir suus: Anna, cur fles? et quare non comedis? et cur mæsto es animo? Nonne ego melior tibi sum quam decem filii?
verses.english: Then Elcana, her husband, said to her, 'Anna, why are you weeping? Why do you refuse to eat? And why is your spirit so downcast? Am I not better to you than ten sons?'

verses.latin: Surrexit Anna postquam comederat et biberat in Silo: Heli autem sacerdos sedebat super sellam ante postes templi Domini.
verses.english: After they had finished eating and drinking in Silo, Anna stood up. Now Eli, the priest, was sitting on his chair by the doorposts of the Lord's house.

verses.latin: Et Anna, amaro animo, oravit Dominum, flens largiter.
verses.english: With a bitter and heavy spirit, Anna prayed to the Lord, weeping profusely.

verses.latin: Et votum vovit, dicens: Domine exercituum, si respiciens videris afflictionem ancillæ tuæ, et memor fueris mei, et non oblitus fueris ancillæ tuæ, dederisque ancillæ tuæ sexum virilem: dabo eum Domino cunctis diebus vitæ ejus, et novacula non ascendet super caput ejus.
verses.english: And she made a solemn vow, saying, 'O Lord of hosts, if You would truly look upon the affliction of Your handmaid, and remember me, and not forget Your handmaid, but grant Your handmaid a male child, then I will give him to the Lord for all the days of his life, and no razor shall ever touch his head—a commitment to a Nazirite vow.'

verses.latin: Factum est autem, cum illa multiplicaret preces coram Domino, ut Heli observaret os ejus.
verses.english: As Anna continued to pray at great length before the Lord, Eli was observing her mouth.

verses.latin: Porro Anna loquebatur in corde suo, tantum labia ejus movebantur, et vox illius non audiebatur. Estimavit ergo Heli eam ebriam.
verses.english: Anna was praying silently within her heart; only her lips were moving, and her voice could not be heard. So Eli thought she was drunk.

verses.latin: Et dixit ei Heli: Usquequo ebria eris? digere paulisper vinum, quo mades.
verses.english: And Eli said to her, 'How long will you be drunk? Put away the wine and sober up!'

verses.latin: Respondens Anna, ait: Non est, domine mi, quia mulier afflicta spiritu ego sum: et vinum, et omne quod inebriare potest, non bibi, sed effudi animam meam coram Domino.
verses.english: Anna answered, 'No, my lord, I am not drunk. I am a woman with a deeply sorrowful spirit. I have drunk no wine or strong drink, but I have poured out my heart before the Lord in prayer.'

verses.latin: Ne reputes ancillam tuam quasi unam de filiabus Belial: quoniam ex multitudine doloris et mæroris mei locuta sum hucusque.
verses.english: Do not take your handmaid for a worthless woman, for it is out of the depth of my great pain and sorrow that I have been speaking up to now.

verses.latin: Respondens autem Heli, ait: Vade in pace: et Deus Israël det petitionem tuam, quam rogasti ab eo.
verses.english: Then Eli answered, 'Go in peace, and may the God of Israel grant you the request you have made of Him.'

verses.latin: Et ait: Inveniat ancilla tua gratiam in oculis tuis. Et abiit mulier in viam suam, et comedit, et vultus illius non sunt amplius in diversa mutati.
verses.english: And Anna said, 'May your handmaid find favor in your sight.' Then the woman went her way, and she ate, and her face was no longer sad.

verses.latin: Et surrexerunt mane, et adoraverunt coram Domino: reversique sunt, et venerunt in domum suam Ramatha. Cognovit autem Elcana uxorem suam Annam, et Dominus recordatus est ejus.
verses.english: They rose early in the morning, worshipped before the Lord, then returned and came to their home in Ramatha. And Elcana was intimate with his wife, Anna, and the Lord remembered her prayer.

verses.latin: Et factum est per revolutionem dierum, et concepit Anna, et peperit filium: vocavitque nomen ejus Samuel, eo quod de Domino postulasset eum.
verses.english: And when the time came around, Anna conceived and bore a son. She named him Samuel, saying, 'Because I asked the Lord for him.'

verses.latin: Et ascendit vir Elcana cum omni domo sua, ut immolaret Domino hostiam solemnem, et votum suum.
verses.english: Then Elcana, her husband, went up with his entire household to offer the annual sacrifice to the Lord and to fulfill his vow.

verses.latin: Anna autem non ascendit, sed dixit viro suo: Usquequo ablactetur puer, et ducam illum, et appareat ante conspectum Domini, et maneat ibi jugiter.
verses.english: But Anna did not go up. Instead, she said to her husband, 'I will wait until the child is weaned. Then I will bring him, so that he may appear before the Lord and remain there in His house always.'

verses.latin: Et dixit ei Elcana vir ejus: Fac quod bonum videtur tibi, et mane hic, donec ablactes eum: tantum suppleat Dominus verbum suum. Mansit ergo mulier, et lactavit filium suum, donec ablactaret eum.
verses.english: Elcana, her husband, said to her, 'Do what seems best to you. Stay here until you have weaned him; only may the Lord establish His word concerning our son.' So the woman stayed home and nursed her son until she weaned him.

verses.latin: Et adduxit eum in Silo, cum ablactasset, in vitulis tribus, et tribus modiis farinæ, et amphora vini, et adduxit eum ad domum Domini in Silo. Puer autem erat adhuc infans.
verses.english: When she had weaned him, she brought him up to Silo, taking with her three calves, three measures of flour, and a jar of wine, as offerings. She brought him to the house of the Lord in Silo. The child was still very young.

verses.latin: Et immolaverunt vitulum, et obtulerunt puerum Heli.
verses.english: Then they sacrificed one of the calves, and Anna brought the child to Eli.

verses.latin: Et dixit Anna: Obsecro, domine mi, vivit anima tua, domine mi: ego sum illa mulier, quæ steti coram te hic orans Dominum.
verses.english: And Anna said, 'Oh, my lord! As surely as you live, my lord, I am the very woman who stood here beside you, praying to the Lord.'

verses.latin: Pro hoc puero oravi, et dedit mihi Dominus petitionem meam, quam postulavi ab eo.
verses.english: It was for this child that I prayed, and the Lord has granted me the request I made of Him.

verses.latin: Idcirco et ego commodavi eum Domino cunctis diebus quibus fuerit, ut commedatus sit Domino. Et adoraverunt ibi Dominum.
verses.english: Therefore, I have dedicated him to the Lord; for as long as he lives, he is dedicated to the Lord.' And they worshipped the Lord there.

verses.latin: Exultavit cor meum in Domino, exaltatum est cornu meum in Deo meo: dilatata est os meum super inimicos meos: quia laetata sum in salutari tuo.
verses.english: My heart has leapt with joy in the Lord God, and my strength—my horn—has been raised up in my God. My mouth is now opened wide to speak confidently against my enemies, because I have rejoiced greatly in your saving power.

verses.latin: Non est sanctus ut est Dominus: neque enim est alius absque te, et non est fortis sicut Deus noster.
verses.english: No one is holy like the Lord God; indeed, there is no one else beside you, and no one is strong like our God.

verses.latin: Nolite multiplicare loqui sublimia, gloriantes: recedant vetera de ore vestro: quoniam Deus scientiarum Dominus est, et ipsi præparantur cogitationes.
verses.english: Do not speak proudly with multiplied boastings; let your former arrogance cease from your mouth. For the Lord God is the God who knows everything, and all thoughts are prepared before Him.

verses.latin: Arcus fortium superatus est, et infirmi accincti sunt robore.
verses.english: The bow of the mighty has been overcome, but the weak have been girded with strength.

verses.latin: Hi qui ante steriles erant, pepererunt plurimos: et quæ multos habebat filios, infirmata est.
verses.english: Those who were barren before have given birth to many children, and she who had many children has become weak.

verses.latin: Dominus mortificat et vivificat, deducit ad inferos et reducit.
verses.english: The Lord God brings death and brings life; He leads down to the realm of the dead and brings back up from it.

verses.latin: Dominus pauperem facit et ditat, humiliat et sublevat.
verses.english: The Lord God makes one poor and makes one rich; He humbles and He exalts.

verses.latin: Suscitans a terra inopem, et de stercore erigens pauperem: ut sedeat cum principibus, et solium gloriæ teneat.
verses.english: He lifts up the needy from the dust of the ground, and raises the poor from the ash heap, to make them sit with princes and inherit a throne of glory.

verses.latin: Domini enim sunt cardines terræ, et posuit super eos orbem.
verses.english: For the pillars of the earth belong to the Lord God, and upon them He has set the world.

verses.latin: Pedes sanctorum suorum servabit, et impii in tenebris conticescent: quia non in fortitudine sua roborabitur vir.
verses.english: He will guard the steps of His faithful ones, but the wicked will be silenced in darkness. For no man will be strong through his own power.

verses.latin: Dominus super eum tonabit de cælis: Dominus judicabit fines terræ, et dabit imperium regi suo, et sublimabit cornu Christi sui.
verses.english: The Lord God will thunder from the heavens against him; the Lord God will judge the ends of the earth, and He will give dominion to His king, and exalt the power—the horn—of His Anointed One.

verses.latin: Et abiit Elcana in Ramatha in domum suam: puer autem erat minister Domini coram Heli sacerdote.
verses.english: And Elcana went to Ramatha, to his home. But the young boy Samuel remained a minister of the Lord God before Heli the priest.

verses.latin: Porro filii Heli filii Belial, nescientes Dominum, neque officium sacerdotum ad populum:
verses.english: Now the sons of Heli were worthless men who did not know the Lord God, nor did they perform the duty of priests toward the people as they should have.

verses.latin: sed et hoc sacerdotum ad populum, quicumque immolasset victimam, veniebat puer sacerdotis, dum coquerentur carnes, et habebat fuscinulam tridentem in manu sua,
verses.english: Indeed, this was the way of the priests with the people: whenever anyone offered a sacrifice, the priest's servant would come while the meat was boiling, and he would have a three-pronged fork in his hand.

verses.latin: et mittebat eam in lebetem, vel in caldariam, vel in ollam, sive in caccabum: et omne quod levabat fuscina, tollebat sacerdos sibi: sic faciebant universo Israëli venientibus in Silo.
verses.english: He would thrust it into the large pot, or into the cauldron, or into the stewpot, or into the small pot, and whatever the fork brought up, the priest would take for himself. This is how they acted with all the people of Israel who came to Silo.

verses.latin: Etiam antequam adolerent adipem, veniebat puer sacerdotis, et dicebat immolanti: Da mihi carnem ut coquam sacerdoti: non enim accipiam a te carnem coctam, sed crudam.
verses.english: Even before they burned the fat of the sacrifice—which was reserved for God—the priest's servant would come and say to the one offering the sacrifice, 'Give me meat to cook for the priest, for I will not accept cooked meat from you, but raw meat.'

verses.latin: Respondebatque illi offerens: Incendatur primum juxta morem hodie adeps, et tolle tibi quantumcumque desiderat anima tua. Qui respondens, aiebat ei: Nequaquam, sed statim dabis: sin autem, tollam vi.
verses.english: And the one offering the sacrifice would answer him, 'Let the fat be burned first today as is the custom, and then take for yourself whatever your heart desires.' But the servant, responding, would say to him, 'Absolutely not! You will give it to me at once. If you do not, I will take it by force.'

verses.latin: Erat ergo peccatum puerorum grande nimis coram Domino: quia retraxerant homines a sacrificio Domini.
verses.english: Therefore, the sin of the young men was excessively great before the Lord God, because they caused people to turn away from the sacrifice due to the Lord God.

verses.latin: Samuhel autem ministrabat ante faciem Domini, puer vestitus ephod lineo.
verses.english: But Samuel, a young boy, ministered before the Lord God, dressed in a linen ephod, a priestly garment.

verses.latin: Et faciebant ei tunicam parvam mater sua, quam afferebat statutis diebus ascendens cum viro suo ut immolaret hostiam solemmen.
verses.english: And his mother used to make him a little tunic, which she would bring to him on the appointed days when she went up with her husband to offer the solemn sacrifice.

verses.latin: Benedixit ergo Heli Elcanæ et uxori ejus, dixitque: Reddat tibi Dominus sobolem de hac muliere, pro fœnore quod commodasti Domino, pro puero. Et abierunt in locum suum.
verses.english: So Heli blessed Elcana and his wife, and said, 'May the Lord God give you offspring from this woman in return for the gift you lent to the Lord God—the boy Samuel.' And they went to their home.

verses.latin: Visitavit itaque Dominus Annam, et concepit, et peperit tres filios, et duas filias: et magnificatus est puer Samuhel apud Dominum.
verses.english: And so, the Lord God visited Hannah, and she conceived and gave birth to three sons and two daughters. And the boy Samuel grew in stature before the Lord God.

verses.latin: Heli autem senuerat nimis, audivitque omnia quæ faciebant filii sui universo Israël, et quomodo dormiebant cum mulieribus quæ observabant ad ostium tabernaculi foederis.
verses.english: Now Heli had grown very old, and he heard all that his sons were doing to all Israel, and how they were sleeping with the women who served at the entrance of the tabernacle of the covenant.

verses.latin: Et dixit eis: Quare facitis res hujuscemodi, quas ego audio, res pessimas, ab omni populo?
verses.english: And he said to them, 'Why are you doing such things, which I hear reported as very wicked deeds by all the people?'

verses.latin: Nolite, filii mei, non enim est bona fama quam ego audio, ut transgredi faciatis populum Domini.
verses.english: 'Do not do this, my sons, for the report I hear is not good. You are causing the Lord God's people to transgress.'

verses.latin: Si peccaverit vir in virum, placari ei potest Deus: si autem in Dominum peccaverit vir, quis orabit pro eo? Et non audierunt vocem patris sui, quia volebat Dominus occidere eos.
verses.english: 'If a man sins against another man, God can intercede for him. But if a man sins against the Lord God, who will intercede for him?' But they did not listen to their father's voice, because the Lord God intended to put them to death.

verses.latin: Puer autem Samuhel proficiebat, et crescebat et gratia apud Dominum et apud homines.
verses.english: But the boy Samuel continued to grow and advance in favor with both the Lord God and with men.

verses.latin: Venit autem vir Dei ad Heli, et ait ad eum: Hæc dicit Dominus: Numquid non aperte revelatus sum domui patris tui, cum essent in Ægypto in domo Pharaonis?
verses.english: Then a man of God came to Heli and said to him, 'Thus says the Lord God: Did I not plainly reveal myself to the house of your father, when they were in Egypt, in the house of Pharaoh?'

verses.latin: Et elegi eum ex omnibus tribubus Israël mihi in sacerdotem, ut ascenderet ad altare meum, et adoleret mihi incensum, et portaret ephod coram me: et dedi domui patris tui omnia de sacrificiis filiorum Israël.
verses.english: 'And I chose him—your ancestor Aaron—from all the tribes of Israel to be My priest, to go up to My altar, and burn incense to Me, and to wear the ephod before Me. And I gave to the house of your father all the offerings of the children of Israel.'

verses.latin: Quare ergo calce abjecistis victimam meam, et munera mea quæ præcepi ut offerrentur in templo: et magis honorasti filios tuos quam me, ut impinguaremini ex primitiis omnis sacrificii mei, Israël?
verses.english: 'Why then have you kicked away My sacrifice and My offerings which I commanded to be presented in the temple? And why have you honored your sons more than Me, so that you yourselves are made fat from the best parts of every sacrifice of My people Israel?'

verses.latin: Propterea hæc dicit Dominus Deus Israël: Loquens locutus sum, ut domus tua et domus patris tui ministraret in conspectu meo usque in æternum. Nunc autem dicit Dominus: Absit hoc a me: sed quicumque glorificaverit me, glorificabo eum: qui autem contemnunt me, erunt ignobiles.
verses.english: 'Therefore, thus says the Lord God of Israel: I indeed said that your house and the house of your father would minister before Me forever. But now the Lord God says: Far be this from Me! Instead, whoever honors Me, I will honor him; but those who despise Me will be made insignificant.'

verses.latin: Ecce dies veniunt, et præcidam brachium tuum, et brachium domus patris tui, ut non sit senex in domo tua.
verses.english: 'Behold, the days are coming when I will cut off your strength—your arm—and the strength of your father's house, so that there will be no old man in your household.'

verses.latin: Et videbis æmulum tuum in templo, in universis prosperis Israël: et non erit senex in domo tua omnibus diebus.
verses.english: 'And you will see an adversary in the temple, amidst all the prosperity of Israel; and there will not be an old man in your house for all your days.'

verses.latin: Hoc autem tibi erit signum, quod eventurum est duobus filiis tuis, Ophni et Phinees: in die una morientur ambo.
verses.english: 'And this will be the sign for you, which will happen to your two sons, Ophni and Phinees: both of them will die on the same day.'

verses.latin: Et suscitabo mihi sacerdotem fidelem, qui juxta cor meum et animam meam faciet: et ædificabo ei domum fidelem, et ambulabit coram Christo meo cunctis diebus.
verses.english: 'And I will raise up for Myself a faithful priest, who will act according to My heart and My soul. And I will build him a sure house, and he will walk before My Anointed One all his days.'

verses.latin: Futurum est autem, ut quicumque remanserit in domo tua, veniat et procidat coram eo pro nummo argenteo, et torta panis, dicatque: Dimitte me, obsecro, ad unam partem sacerdotalem, ut comedam buccellam panis.
verses.english: 'And it will come to pass that everyone who remains in your house will come and bow down before him for a piece of silver and a loaf of bread, and say, 'Please, assign me to one of the priestly portions, so that I may eat a morsel of bread.''

verses.latin: Et oravit Anna, et ait: Exsultavit cor meum in Domino, exaltatum est cornu meum in Deo meo: dilatata est os meum super inimicos meos: quia laetata sum in salutari tuo.
verses.english: And Anna prayed, saying: 'My heart has rejoiced in the Lord; my strength, like a horn lifted high, has been made great by my God. My voice now speaks triumphantly over my enemies, because I have found great joy in Your deliverance.'

verses.latin: Non est sanctus ut est Dominus: neque enim est alius absque te, et non est fortis sicut Deus noster.
verses.english: There is no one holy like the Lord; indeed, there is no other God besides You, and no one is as strong as our God.

verses.latin: Nolite multiplicare loqui sublimia, gloriantes: recedant vetera de ore vestro: quia Deus scientiarum Dominus est, et ipsi parantur cogitationes.
verses.english: Do not speak many proud and boastful words; let arrogance depart from your mouths. For the Lord is the God of all knowledge, and He weighs every thought and intention.

verses.latin: Arcus fortium superatus est, et infirmi accincti sunt robore.
verses.english: The bows of the mighty are broken, but those who were weak are now girded with strength.

verses.latin: Repleti prius, pro pane locati sunt: et famelici saturati sunt, ut sterilis peperit plurimos: et quae multos habebat filios, infirmata est.
verses.english: Those who were once full and well-fed are now reduced to working for bread, while those who were starving are now satisfied. Even the barren woman has borne many children, and she who had many children has become feeble and desolate.

verses.latin: Dominus mortificat et vivificat, deducit ad inferos et reducit.
verses.english: The Lord brings death and brings life; He leads down to the realm of the dead and brings back up again.

verses.latin: Dominus pauperem facit et ditat, humiliat et sublevat.
verses.english: The Lord makes one poor and makes one rich; He humbles and He exalts.

verses.latin: Suscitat de pulvere egenum, et de stercore elevat pauperem: ut sedeat cum principibus, et solium gloriae teneat. Domini enim sunt cardines terrae, et posuit super eos orbem.
verses.english: He lifts the needy from the dust and raises the poor from the ash heap, to make them sit with princes and inherit a glorious throne. For the foundations of the earth are the Lord's, and He has established the world upon them.

verses.latin: Pedes sanctorum suorum servabit, et impii in tenebris conticescent: quia non in fortitudine sua roborabitur vir.
verses.english: He will guard the steps of His saints, but the wicked will be silenced in darkness. For no one is strong by their own might.

verses.latin: Dominum formidabunt adversarii ejus: et super ipsos in caelis tonabit. Dominus judicabit fines terrae, et dabit imperium Regi suo, et sublimabit cornu Christi sui.
verses.english: His adversaries will fear the Lord; over them He will thunder from the universe. The Lord will judge the ends of the earth, and He will give power to His King, and He will exalt the strength of His Anointed One.

verses.latin: Et abiit Elcana in Ramatha in domum suam: puer autem erat minister Domini coram Heli sacerdote.
verses.english: Then Elcana went to his home in Ramatha. But the child Samuel remained as a minister of the Lord, serving before Eli the priest.

verses.latin: Filii autem Heli, filii Belial, nescientes Dominum,
verses.english: Now the sons of Eli were wicked men, sons of Belial, who did not know or acknowledge the Lord.

verses.latin: neque officium sacerdotum ad populum: sed et quicumque immolasset victimam, veniebat puer sacerdotis, dum coquerentur carnes, et habebat fuscinulam tridentem in manu sua,
verses.english: Nor did they respect the priests' duty to the people. When anyone offered a sacrifice, the priest's servant would come while the meat was boiling, holding a three-pronged fork in his hand.

verses.latin: et immittibat eam in lebetem, vel in caldariam, vel in ollam, sive in caccabum: et omne quod levabat fuscinula, tollebat sacerdos sibi: sic faciebant universo Israeli venientibus in Silo.
verses.english: And he would thrust it into the cauldron, or the pot, or the kettle, or the pan. Whatever the fork brought up, the priest would take for himself. This is how they treated all the Israelites who came to Silo.

verses.latin: Etiam antequam adolerent adipem, veniebat puer sacerdotis, et dicebat immolanti: Da mihi carnem ut coquam sacerdoti: non enim accipiam a te carnem coctam, sed crudam.
verses.english: Even before the fat was burned as an offering, the priest's servant would come and say to the one offering the sacrifice: 'Give me meat to roast for the priest, for I will not accept cooked meat from you, but only raw meat.'

verses.latin: Respondebatque vir: Incendatur primum juxta morem hodie adeps, et tolle tibi quantumcumque desiderat anima tua. Qui aiebat ei: Nequaquam: sed statim dabis, alioquin tollam per violentiam.
verses.english: And the man offering the sacrifice would answer him: 'Let the fat be burned first today, as is the custom, then take for yourself whatever your soul desires.' But the servant would say to him: 'No, by no means; you must give it to me immediately, or else I will take it by force.'

verses.latin: Erat ergo peccatum puerorum grande nimis coram Domino: quia retrahebant homines a sacrificio Domini.
verses.english: Therefore, the sin of these young men was exceedingly great before the Lord, because they were causing men to withdraw from offering sacrifice to the Lord.

verses.latin: Samuel autem ministrabat ante faciem Domini, puer accinctus ephod lineo.
verses.english: But Samuel, the young boy, ministered before the Lord, clothed with a linen ephod, a sacred garment.

verses.latin: Et tunicam parvam faciebat ei mater sua, quam afferebat statutis diebus ascendens cum viro suo, ut immolaret hostiam solemne.
verses.english: And his mother used to make him a little tunic, which she would bring to him year after year, when she would go up with her husband to offer the yearly sacrifice.

verses.latin: Et benedixit Heli Elcanae, et uxori ejus, dixitque: Reddat tibi Dominus semen de muliere hac pro fœnerato, quod commodasti Domino. Et abierunt in locum suum.
verses.english: And Eli blessed Elcana and his wife, and he said: 'May the Lord grant you offspring from this woman in return for the one that was given to the Lord.' Then they went to their home.

verses.latin: Visitavit ergo Dominus Annam, et concepit, et peperit tres filios, et duas filias: et magnificatus est puer Samuel apud Dominum.
verses.english: So the Lord visited Anna, and she conceived and gave birth to three sons and two daughters. And the boy Samuel grew in importance before the Lord.

verses.latin: Heli autem senuerat nimis, et audivit omnia quae faciebant filii sui universo Israeli: et quomodo dormiebant cum mulieribus, quae observabant ad ostium tabernaculi foederis.
verses.english: Now Eli was very old, and he heard all that his sons were doing to all of Israel; specifically, how they were lying with the women who served at the entrance of the tabernacle of the covenant.

verses.latin: Et dixit eis: Quare facitis res hujuscemodi, quas ego audio, res pessimas, de omni populo?
verses.english: And he said to them: 'Why are you doing such things? I hear of these very wicked deeds from all the people.'

verses.latin: Nolite, filii mei, non enim est bona fama, quam ego audio, ut transire faciatis populum Domini.
verses.english: 'Do not, my sons, for the report I hear is not good, that you cause the Lord's people to transgress.'

verses.latin: Si peccaverit vir in virum, placari ei potest Deus: si autem in Dominum peccaverit vir, quis orabit pro eo? Et non audierunt vocem patris sui, quia voluit Dominus occidere eos.
verses.english: If a man sins against another man, God can intercede for him; but if a man sins against the Lord, who can pray for him? But they did not listen to the voice of their father, for the Lord had already decided to put them to death.

verses.latin: Puer autem Samuel proficiebat, et crescebat, et placebat tam Domino, quam hominibus.
verses.english: But the boy Samuel continued to grow and advance in stature and favor, pleasing both the Lord and mankind.

verses.latin: Venit autem vir Dei ad Heli, et ait ad eum: Hæc dicit Dominus: Numquid non aperte revelatus sum domui patris tui, cum essent in Ægypto in domo Pharaonis?
verses.english: Then a man of God came to Eli and said to him: 'Thus says the Lord: Did I not clearly reveal Myself to the house of your father, when they were in Egypt, in the house of Pharaoh?'

verses.latin: Et elegi eum ex omnibus tribubus Israel mihi in sacerdotem, ad ascendendum ad altare meum, et ad comburendum mihi incensum, et ad portandum ephod coram me: et dedi domui patris tui omnia de sacrificiis filiorum Israel.
verses.english: 'And I chose him from all the tribes of Israel to be My priest, to ascend to My altar, to burn incense for Me, and to wear the ephod before Me. And I gave to the house of your father all the fire offerings of the sons of Israel.'

verses.latin: Quare calce abjecistis victimam meam, et munera mea, quæ præcepi ut offerrentur in templo: et magis honorasti filios tuos quam me, ut impinguaretis vos ex primitiis omnis sacrificii Israel servi mei?
verses.english: 'Why then have you kicked aside My sacrifice and My offerings, which I commanded to be offered in the temple? And why have you honored your sons more than Me, enriching yourselves with the best parts of every sacrifice of My servant Israel?'

verses.latin: Propterea, ait Dominus Deus Israel: Loquens locutus sum, quia domus tua, et domus patris tui, ministrabunt in conspectu meo usque in æternum. Nunc autem dicit Dominus: Absit hoc a me: sed quicumque glorificaverit me, glorificabo eum: qui autem contemnunt me, erunt ignobiles.
verses.english: Therefore, the Lord, the God of Israel, declares: 'I indeed said that your house and the house of your father would minister before Me forever. But now the Lord says: Far be it from Me! Rather, whoever glorifies Me, him will I glorify; but those who despise Me shall be brought to dishonor.'

verses.latin: Ecce dies veniunt, et præcidam brachium tuum, et brachium domus patris tui, ut non sit senex in domo tua.
verses.english: 'Behold, the days are coming when I will cut off your strength and the strength of your father's house, so that there will be no old man in your house.'

verses.latin: Et videbis æmulum tuum in templo, in universis prosperis Israel: et non erit senex in domo tua omnibus diebus.
verses.english: 'And you will see an adversary in My dwelling place, amidst all the prosperity of Israel, yet there will be no old man in your house for all your days.'

verses.latin: Verumtamen unum de tuis non auferam ab altari meo, ut deficiant oculi ejus, et tabescat anima ejus: et omnis progenies domus tuæ morietur cum virili ætate.
verses.english: 'Nevertheless, I will not cut off every last one of yours from My altar, but only so that his eyes may fail and his soul waste away. And all the offspring of your house will die in the prime of their lives.'

verses.latin: Hoc autem tibi erit signum, quod venturum est in duobus filiis tuis, Ophni et Phinees: in die una morientur ambo.
verses.english: 'And this will be the sign for you, which is about to come to pass regarding your two sons, Ophni and Phinees: on one day, both will die.'

verses.latin: Et suscitabo mihi sacerdotem fidelem, qui juxta cor meum et animam meam faciet: et ædificabo ei domum fidelem, et ambulabit coram Christo meo cunctis diebus.
verses.english: 'And I will raise up for Myself a faithful priest who will act according to My heart and My soul. And I will build him a faithful house, and he will walk before My Anointed One all his days.'

verses.latin: Futurum est autem, ut quicumque reliquus fuerit in domo tua, veniat, et procidat pro eo ut accipiat nummum argenteum, et tortam panis, et dicat: Dimitte me, obsecro, ad unam partem sacerdotalem, ut comedam buccellam panis.
verses.english: 'And it shall come to pass that everyone who is left in your house will come and bow down before him to receive a silver coin and a loaf of bread, and will say: 'Please, let me belong to one of the priestly portions, so that I may eat a morsel of bread.''

verses.latin: Non est enim versiculus trigesimus septimus.
verses.english: There is no thirty-seventh verse.

verses.latin: Non est enim versiculus trigesimus octavus.
verses.english: There is no thirty-eighth verse.

verses.latin: Non est enim versiculus trigesimus nonus.
verses.english: There is no thirty-ninth verse.

verses.latin: Non est enim versiculus quadragesimus.
verses.english: There is no fortieth verse.

verses.latin: Puer autem Samuel ministrabat Domino coram Heli: et sermo Domini erat pretiosus in diebus illis, non erat visio manifesta.
verses.english: The boy Samuel was serving the Lord in the presence of Eli, but in those days, the word of the Lord was rare, and there were no clear visions or prophecies from God.

verses.latin: Et factum est in die quadam, dormiebat Heli in loco suo: et oculi ejus caligaverant, nec poterat videre.
verses.english: And it came to pass on a certain occasion that Eli was sleeping in his customary place. His eyes had grown so dim that he could not see.

verses.latin: Antequam lucernae Dei extinguerentur, Samuel dormiebat in templo Domini, ubi erat arca Dei.
verses.english: Before the lamps in the house of God had been extinguished for the morning, Samuel was sleeping in the Lord's sanctuary, where the Ark of God was kept.

verses.latin: Et vocavit Dominus Samuelem. Qui respondens, ait: Ecce ego.
verses.english: And the Lord called Samuel. Samuel answered, saying, 'Here I am.'

verses.latin: Et cucurrit ad Heli, et dixit: Ecce ego: vocasti enim me. Qui ait: Non vocavi: revertere et dormi. Et abiit, et dormivit.
verses.english: So Samuel ran to Eli and said, 'Here I am, for you called me.' Eli replied, 'I did not call you. Go back to sleep.' So Samuel went and lay down again.

verses.latin: Et adjecit Dominus rursum ut vocaret Samuelem. Et consurgens Samuel, abiit ad Heli, et ait: Ecce ego: vocasti enim me. Qui respondit: Non vocavi te, fili mi: revertere et dormi.
verses.english: And the Lord called Samuel again. Samuel got up, went to Eli, and said, 'Here I am, for you called me.' Eli answered, 'I did not call you, my son. Go back to sleep.'

verses.latin: Porro Samuel necdum sciebat Dominum, neque revelatus fuerat ei sermo Domini.
verses.english: Now Samuel did not yet know the Lord personally in this manner, nor had the word of the Lord been revealed to him in such a way before.

verses.latin: Et adjecit Dominus et vocavit Samuelem tertio. Qui consurgens, abiit ad Heli, et ait: Ecce ego: vocasti enim me. Intellexit igitur Heli, quia Dominus vocaret puerum.
verses.english: And the Lord called Samuel a third time. Samuel rose, went to Eli, and said, 'Here I am, for you called me.' Then Eli understood that it was the Lord calling the boy.

verses.latin: Et dixit Heli ad Samuelem: Vade, et dormi: et si deinceps vocaverit te, dices: Loquere, Domine, quia audit servus tuus. Abiit ergo Samuel, et dormivit in loco suo.
verses.english: So Eli said to Samuel, 'Go and sleep. If He calls you again, you are to say, 'Speak, Lord, for your servant is listening.'' So Samuel went and lay down in his place.

verses.latin: Et venit Dominus, et stetit: et vocavit, sicut vocaverat prius: Samuel, Samuel. Et ait Samuel: Loquere, Domine, quia audit servus tuus.
verses.english: And the Lord came and stood there, and called as He had called before, 'Samuel, Samuel!' And Samuel said, 'Speak, Lord, for your servant is listening.'

verses.latin: Et dixit Dominus ad Samuelem: Ecce ego facio verbum in Israel, quod quicumque audierit, tinnient ambae aures ejus.
verses.english: And the Lord said to Samuel, 'Behold, I am about to do something in Israel that will make both ears of everyone who hears of it ring with shock.'

verses.latin: In die illa suscitabo super Heli omnia quae locutus sum adversum domum ejus: incipiam, et perficiam.
verses.english: 'On that very day, I will carry out against Eli everything I have spoken against his house, from beginning to end.'

verses.latin: Praedixi enim ei quod judicaturus essem domum ejus in æternum, propter iniquitatem filiorum ejus detrahentium Deo, et non castigavit eos.
verses.english: 'For I have told him that I will judge his house forever because of the iniquity of his sons, who have blasphemed God, and he did not restrain them.'

verses.latin: Idcirco juravi domui Heli, si expietur iniquitas domus ejus victimis et muneribus usque in æternum.
verses.english: 'Therefore, I have sworn to the house of Eli: The iniquity of his house shall never be atoned for by sacrifice or offering, not for all time.'

verses.latin: Dormivit autem Samuel usque mane, et aperuit ostia domus Domini. Timebat autem Samuel indicare visionem Heli.
verses.english: So Samuel slept until morning, and then he opened the doors of the Lord's house. But Samuel was afraid to tell Eli the vision.

verses.latin: Vocavit ergo Heli Samuelem, et dixit: Samuel, fili mi. Qui respondens, ait: Ecce ego.
verses.english: Eli then called Samuel and said, 'Samuel, my son.' And Samuel answered, 'Here I am.'

verses.latin: Et ait: Quis est sermo, qui factus est ad te? oro te, ne celaveris me: hæc faciat tibi Deus, et hæc addat, si absconderis a me uno ex omnibus verbis quæ dicta sunt tibi.
verses.english: Eli said, 'What is the message that was given to you? I implore you, do not hide it from me. May God do to you even worse, if you hide from me even one of all the words that were spoken to you.'

verses.latin: Indicavit ergo ei Samuel universos sermones, et non abscondit ab eo quidquam. Et ille respondit: Dominus est: quod bonum est in oculis suis, faciat.
verses.english: So Samuel told him all the words and hid nothing from him. Eli then responded, 'It is the Lord; let Him do what is good in His sight.'

verses.latin: Crevit autem Samuel, et Dominus erat cum eo, et non cecidit de omnibus verbis ejus in terram.
verses.english: Samuel grew, and the Lord was with him, and none of His words that He spoke through Samuel fell to the ground unfulfilled.

verses.latin: Et cognovit omnis Israel ab Dan usque Bersabee, quod fidelis Samuel propheta esset Domino.
verses.english: And all Israel, from Dan even to Beersheba, recognized that Samuel was a faithful prophet of the Lord.

verses.latin: Et addidit Dominus ut appareret in Silo, quoniam revelatus fuerat Samueli sermo Domini in Silo, juxta verbum Domini.
verses.english: And the Lord continued to appear in Shiloh, because the Lord revealed Himself to Samuel in Shiloh through the word of the Lord.

verses.latin: Factum est ergo in diebus illis, ut Philisthim congregarentur in pugnam: et egressus est Israel obviam Philisthim in prælium, et castra metati sunt juxta locum qui vocatur Lapis Adjutorii.
verses.english: It happened during that time that the Philistines gathered their forces for war. The people of Israel went out to fight against them, and set up their camp near a place called Ebenezer—which means 'Stone of Help'.

verses.latin: Instruxitque aciem Israel contra Philisthim: et commisso certamine, terga vertit Israel Philisthim: cæsa sunt ibi ex Israel quasi triginta millia peditum.
verses.english: Israel lined up for battle against the Philistines. When the fighting began, the people of Israel turned and fled from the Philistines. About thirty thousand of Israel’s foot soldiers were killed there.

verses.latin: Et reversus est populus in castra: dixeruntque majores natu de Israel: Quare percussit nos Dominus hodie coram Philisthim? Afferamus ad nos de Silo arcam fœderis Domini, et veniat in medium nostri, ut salvet nos de manu inimicorum nostrorum.
verses.english: When the surviving people returned to their camp, the leading elders of Israel said: 'Why did the Lord allow the Philistines to defeat us today? Let us bring the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord from Shiloh, and let it come into our midst. Then it will save us from the power of our enemies.'

verses.latin: Misit ergo populus in Silo, et tulerunt inde arcam fœderis Domini exercituum sedentis super Cherubim: erantque duo filii Heli cum arca fœderis Dei, Ophni et Phinees.
verses.english: So the people sent word to Shiloh, and they brought from there the Ark of the Covenant of the Lord of Hosts, who sits enthroned above the Cherubim. Eli’s two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, were with the Ark of God's Covenant.

verses.latin: Cumque venisset arca fœderis Domini in castra, conclamavit omnis Israel clamore magno, et reboavit terra.
verses.english: When the Ark of the Lord's Covenant arrived in the camp, all of Israel shouted with a great outcry, and the entire land echoed with the sound.

verses.latin: Et audierunt Philisthim vocem clamoris: dixeruntque: Quæ est hæc vox clamoris magni in castris Hebræorum? Et cognoverunt quod arca Domini venisset in castra.
verses.english: The Philistines heard the sound of the outcry and asked: 'What is this sound of a great shout in the camp of the Hebrews?' They quickly realized that the Ark of the Lord had come into their camp.

verses.latin: Et timuerunt Philisthim, dicentes: Venit Deus in castra. Et ingemuerunt, dicentes:
verses.english: Then the Philistines became afraid and said: 'God has come into their camp!' They groaned in fear and said:

verses.latin: Væ nobis: quia non fuit tanta exultatio heri et nudiustertius: Væ nobis. Quis nos salvabit de manu Dei istius excelsi? Hi sunt dii qui percusserunt Ægyptum omni plaga in deserto.
verses.english: 'Woe to us! Nothing like this great rejoicing has happened before, not yesterday nor the day before! Woe to us! Who will save us from the power of this mighty God? These are the gods who struck Egypt with every kind of plague in the wilderness.'

verses.latin: Confortamini, et estote viri, Philisthim: ne serviatis Hebræis, sicut et illi servierunt vobis: estote viri, et pugnate.
verses.english: 'Be strong, Philistines! Act like men! Do not serve the Hebrews, just as they have served you. Be men, and fight!'

verses.latin: Pugnaverunt ergo Philisthim, et cæsus est Israel, et fugit unusquisque in tabernaculum suum: et facta est plaga magna nimis, et ceciderunt de Israel triginta millia virorum.
verses.english: So the Philistines fought, and Israel was defeated, and every man fled to his tent. The slaughter was exceedingly great, and thirty thousand men of Israel fell dead.

verses.latin: Et arca Dei capta est: et duo filii Heli mortui sunt, Ophni et Phinees.
verses.english: And the Ark of God was captured. Eli's two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, died.

verses.latin: Currens autem vir de Benjamin de acie, venit in Silo in die illa, scissa veste, et pulvere aspersus caput.
verses.english: But a man from the tribe of Benjamin ran from the battle line and came to Shiloh that same day. His clothes were torn, and his head was covered with dust, showing his grief and distress.

verses.latin: Cumque ille venisset, Heli sedebat super sellam contra viam, prospiciens: erat enim cor ejus pavidum pro arca Domini. Vir autem ille postquam ingressus est, nuntiavit civitati: et ululavit omnis civitas.
verses.english: When he arrived, Eli was sitting on a chair beside the road, looking out—for his heart was trembling with fear for the Ark of God. After the man entered, he announced the news to the city, and the entire city cried out in lament.

verses.latin: Et audivit Heli vocem clamoris: et dixit: Quis est hic sonus tumultus hujus? Ille autem festinavit, et venit, et nuntiavit Heli.
verses.english: Eli heard the sound of the outcry and asked: 'What is this sound of a great uproar?' The man hurried, came to Eli, and told him the news.

verses.latin: Heli autem nonaginta annorum et octo erat, et oculi ejus caligaverant, et videre non poterat.
verses.english: Eli was ninety-eight years old, and his eyes had grown dim, so he could not see.

verses.latin: Et dixit ad Heli: Ego sum qui veni de prælio, et ego de acie fugi hodie. Cui ille ait: Quid factum est fili mi?
verses.english: The man said to Eli: 'I am the one who came from the battle. I fled from the battle line today.' Eli then asked him: 'What happened, my son?'

verses.latin: Respondens autem ille, qui nuntiabat: Fugit, inquit, Israel coram Philisthim, et ruina magna facta est in populo: insuper et duo filii tui mortui sunt, Ophni et Phinees: et arca Dei capta est.
verses.english: The messenger answered: 'Israel has fled before the Philistines, and a great slaughter has occurred among the people. Moreover, your two sons, Hophni and Phinehas, are dead. And the Ark of God has been captured.'

verses.latin: Cumque ille nominasset arcam Dei, corruit de sella retrorsum juxta ostium, et confractis cervicibus mortuus est. Senex enim erat vir et gravis. Et ipse judicavit Israel quadraginta annis.
verses.english: When the messenger mentioned the Ark of God, Eli fell backward from his chair beside the gate. His neck was broken, and he died. For the man was old and heavy. He had judged Israel for forty years.

verses.latin: Nurus quoque ejus uxor Phinees, prægnans erat propinqua partui: et audito nuntio quod capta esset arca Dei, et mortuus esset socer suus et vir suus, incurvavit se et peperit: irruerant enim in eam dolores subiti.
verses.english: His daughter-in-law, Phinehas’s wife, was pregnant and close to giving birth. When she heard the news that the Ark of God had been captured and that her father-in-law and her husband had died, she bowed down and gave birth, for sudden labor pains came upon her.

verses.latin: In ipso autem momento, per quo moriebatur, dixerunt ei quæ stabant circa eam: Ne timeas, quia filium peperisti. Et illa non respondit, nec animadvertit ad cor suum.
verses.english: Just as she was dying, those who stood around her said: 'Do not fear, for you have given birth to a son!' But she did not answer, nor did she pay attention to their words.

verses.latin: Et vocavit nomen pueri Ichabod, dicens: Translata est gloria de Israel: eo quod capta esset arca Dei, et propter socerum suum, et virum suum.
verses.english: And she named the child Ichabod, saying: 'The glory has departed from Israel,' because the Ark of God had been captured, and because of her father-in-law and her husband.

verses.latin: Translata est gloria de Israel, eo quod capta esset arca Dei.
verses.english: She emphasized, 'The glory has departed from Israel, because the Ark of God has been captured!'

verses.latin: Philisthiim autem tulerunt arcam Dei, et asportaverunt de lapide Adjutorii in Azotum.
verses.english: And the Philistines took the Ark of God, carrying it away from the Stone of Help—the place where Israel was defeated—to the city of Ashdod.

verses.latin: Tuleruntque Philisthiim arcam Dei, et intulerunt eam in templum Dagon, et statuerunt juxta Dagon.
verses.english: So the Philistines took the Ark of God into the temple of their god Dagon and set it up right next to the idol of Dagon.

verses.latin: Cumque surrexissent Azotii altera die, ecce Dagon jacebat pronus in terra ante arcam Domini: et tulerunt Dagon, et restituerunt eum in locum suum.
verses.english: When the people of Ashdod woke up the next morning, they found Dagon lying face down on the ground before the Ark of the Lord. So they picked up Dagon and put him back in his place.

verses.latin: Rursumque diluculo die altera consurgentes, invenerunt Dagon jacentem super terram pronum ante arcam Domini: et caput Dagon, et duae palmae manuum ejus abscissae erant super limen: Sola autem truncus Dagon remanserat.
verses.english: But when they got up early the following morning, they again found Dagon lying face down on the ground before the Ark of the Lord. This time, Dagon's head and both of his hands were cut off and lying on the threshold of the temple, with only the trunk of Dagon's body remaining intact.

verses.latin: Ob hanc causam non calcant sacerdotes Dagon, et omnes qui ingrediuntur templum, super limen Dagon in Azoto usque in hodiernum diem.
verses.english: Because of this event, the priests of Dagon and all who enter the temple of Dagon in Ashdod have not stepped on the threshold of Dagon, even to this very day.

verses.latin: Aggravata est autem manus Domini super Azotios, et demolitus est eos: et percussit in sedibus suis Azotum et fines ejus, et ebullierunt super eos inguinum tumores.
verses.english: But the hand of the Lord weighed heavily upon the people of Ashdod, and He devastated them. He struck the people of Ashdod and their surrounding territory in their own homes, causing painful tumors to break out on them.

verses.latin: Videntesque viri Azotii huiusmodi plagam, dixerunt: Non maneat arca Dei Israel nobiscum, quoniam gravis est manus ejus super nos, et super Dagon deum nostrum.
verses.english: When the men of Ashdod saw the nature of this plague, they said, "The Ark of the God of Israel must not remain with us, because His hand is heavy upon us and upon Dagon, our god."

verses.latin: Et mittentes congregaverunt universos principes Philisthiim ad se, et dixerunt: Quid faciemus de arca Dei Israel? Responderuntque: In Geth circumferatur arca Dei Israel. Et circumfertur arca Dei Israel.
verses.english: So they sent for and gathered all the rulers of the Philistines to them and asked, "What shall we do with the Ark of the God of Israel?" They answered, "Let the Ark of the God of Israel be taken around to Gath." So the Ark of the God of Israel was carried there.

verses.latin: Et facta est, postquam circumfertur, manus Domini super civitatem in interitu magno nimis: et percussit viros civitatis a parvo usque ad magnum, et ebullierunt super eos inguinum tumores.
verses.english: After it was carried to Gath, the hand of the Lord fell upon that city with extremely great destruction. He struck the men of the city, from the youngest to the oldest, and painful tumors broke out on them.

verses.latin: Miserunt ergo arcam Dei in Accaron. Cumque venisset arca Dei in Accaron, exclamaverunt Accaronitae dicentes: Adduxerunt ad nos arcam Dei Israel ut interficerent nos et populum nostrum.
verses.english: So they sent the Ark of God to Ekron. When the Ark of God arrived in Ekron, the people of Ekron cried out, saying, "They have brought the Ark of the God of Israel to us, intending to kill us and our people!"

verses.latin: Miserunt ergo, et congregaverunt omnes principes Philisthiim: et dixerunt: Dimittite arcam Dei Israel, et revertatur in locum suum, et non interficiat nos et populum nostrum. Confusio enim mortis facta est in omni civitate, et ingravata est nimis manus Dei.
verses.english: So they sent and gathered all the rulers of the Philistines, and they said, "Send away the Ark of the God of Israel! Let it return to its own place, so it will not kill us and our people." For a confusion of death—a deadly panic—had spread throughout the entire city, and the hand of God was very heavy there.

verses.latin: Viri quoque qui non moriebantur, vexabantur tumoribus inguinum: et ascendebat ululatus uniuscujusque civitatis usque ad caelum.
verses.english: Even the men who did not die were tormented with tumors, and the wailing of each city went up to the sky.

verses.latin: Philistim vero tulerunt arcam Dei, et asportaverunt de lapide Adiutorii in Azotum.
verses.english: The Philistines took the Ark of God, and carried it away from the Stone of Help to Azotus.

verses.latin: Et introduxerunt Philistim arcam Dei in templum Dagon, et statuerunt eam juxta Dagon.
verses.english: And the Philistines brought the Ark of God into the temple of Dagon, and set it beside Dagon.

verses.latin: Cumque surrexissent Azotii altera die, ecce Dagon jacebat pronus in terram ante arcam Domini: et tulerunt Dagon, et restituerunt eum in locum suum.
verses.english: But when the people of Azotus arose the next day, behold, Dagon was lying face down on the ground before the Ark of the Lord; so they took Dagon and put him back in his place.

verses.latin: Et rursum mane die altera consurgentes, invenerunt Dagon jacentem super terram faciem suam in terra coram arca Domini: et caput Dagon, et duae palmae manuum ejus abscissae erant super limen: Sola autem pars Dagon steterat.
verses.english: And again, when they arose early on the next day, they found Dagon lying on the ground, face down before the Ark of the Lord; and the head of Dagon and both of his hands were cut off, lying on the threshold. Only Dagon's torso remained intact.

verses.latin: Propter hanc causam non calcant sacerdotes Dagon, et omnes qui ingrediuntur templum Dagon in Azoto, super limen Dagon, usque in hodiernum diem.
verses.english: Because of this, the priests of Dagon and all who enter the temple of Dagon in Azotus do not step on Dagon's threshold, even to this day.

verses.latin: Aggravata est autem manus Domini super Azotios, et demolitus est eos: et percussit eos in sedibus tumoriis, Azotum et fines ejus.
verses.english: And the hand of the Lord grew heavy upon the people of Azotus; He utterly destroyed them, and struck them with tumors in their secret parts, both Azotus and its surrounding areas.

verses.latin: Videntes autem viri Azotii plagam, dixerunt: Non maneat arca Dei Israel nobiscum, quoniam gravis est manus ejus super nos, et super Dagon deum nostrum.
verses.english: When the men of Azotus saw the plague, they said: "The Ark of the God of Israel must not remain with us, because His hand is heavy upon us and upon Dagon our god."

verses.latin: Et mittentes congregaverunt universos satrapas Philistim ad se, et dixerunt: Quid faciemus de arca Dei Israel? Responderuntque: Ad Geth circumferatur arca Dei Israel. Et circumtulerunt arcam Dei Israel.
verses.english: So they sent for and gathered all the lords of the Philistines to them, and said: "What shall we do with the Ark of the God of Israel?" They answered: "Let the Ark of the God of Israel be carried to Geth." And so they carried the Ark of the God of Israel there.

verses.latin: Et factum est cum pertulissent eam, facta est manus Domini super civitatem interfectione magna nimis: et percussit viros civitatis a parvo usque ad magnum, et ebullierunt in eis sedes tumorum.
verses.english: And it came to pass, after they had carried it there, the hand of the Lord fell upon the city with a very great destruction; He struck the men of the city, both small and great, and tumors erupted upon them in their secret parts.

verses.latin: Miserunt ergo arcam Dei in Accaron. Cumque venisset arca Dei in Accaron, exclamaverunt Accaronitae, dicentes: Adduxerunt ad nos arcam Dei Israel ut interficeret nos, et populum nostrum.
verses.english: So they sent the Ark of God to Accaron. When the Ark of God came to Accaron, the people of Accaron cried out, saying: "They have brought the Ark of the God of Israel to us, to kill us and our people!"

verses.latin: Miserunt ergo, et congregaverunt omnes satrapas Philistim: et dixerunt: Dimittite arcam Dei Israel, et revertatur in locum suum, et non interficiat nos, et populum nostrum. Facta fuerat enim mortalitas in tota civitate, et ingens terror: et gravata erat nimis manus Dei.
verses.english: Therefore, they sent for and gathered all the lords of the Philistines, and said: "Send away the Ark of the God of Israel, and let it return to its own place, so that it may not kill us and our people." For there had been a deadly plague throughout the entire city, and a great terror; and the hand of God was exceedingly heavy upon them.

verses.latin: Viri quoque qui non moriebantur, percutiebantur in sedibus tumoriis: et ascendebat clamor uniuscujusque civitatis usque ad caelum.
verses.english: And those men who did not die were struck with tumors in their secret parts; and the cry of each city ascended even to the heavens.

verses.latin: Facta est autem arca Domini in terra Philisthinorum septem mensibus.
verses.english: The Ark of the Lord had remained in the land of the Philistines for seven months.

verses.latin: Et vocaverunt Philisthim sacerdotes et divinos dicentes: Quid faciemus de arca Domini? Quomodo remittemus eam in locum suum?
verses.english: So the Philistines called for their priests and diviners, asking, 'What should we do with the Ark of the Lord? How can we send it back to its rightful place?'

verses.latin: Qui responderunt: Si remittitis arcam Dei Israel, nolite dimittere eam vacuam, sed quod debetis reddite ei pro peccato, et tunc curabimini: et scietis quare non recedat manus eius a vobis.
verses.english: They answered, 'If you are going to send back the Ark of the God of Israel, do not send it back empty. Instead, you must give Him a guilt offering for the sin you have committed. Then you will be healed, and you will understand why His hand has not stopped punishing you.'

verses.latin: Dixeruntque: Quae est culpa quam reddere debemus ei?
verses.english: Then the Philistines asked, 'What sort of guilt offering should we return to Him?'

verses.latin: Qui responderunt: Secundum numerum principum Philisthinorum, quinque anos aureos, et quinque mures aureos: quia plaga una fuit omnibus vobis, et optimatibus vestris.
verses.english: They replied, 'You must make five golden tumors, representing the plague’s effect, and five golden mice, according to the number of the Philistine rulers. This is because there was one plague afflicting all of you and your leaders.'

verses.latin: Quare ergo ingravescitis corda vestra, sicut ingravavit cor Aegyptus et Pharao? Nonne postquam percussit eos, tunc dimiserunt eos, et abierunt?
verses.english: Why do you harden your hearts, just as the Egyptians and Pharaoh hardened theirs? After God struck them with plagues, did they not then let the Israelites go, and they departed?

verses.latin: Nunc ergo facite carrum novum unum: et bigas duas lactantes, quibus nunquam impositum est jugum, jungite ad currum: et recludite eas domi, et vitulos earum reducite post eas.
verses.english: Now then, make a new cart. Take two nursing cows that have never been yoked, and harness them to the cart. Shut up their calves at home, so they cannot follow their mothers.

verses.latin: Et tollite arcam Domini, et ponite in curru: et vasa aurea, quae reddere ei debetis pro peccato, ponite in capsella ad latus eius: et dimittite eam ut vadat.
verses.english: Then take the Ark of the Lord and place it on the cart. Put the golden offerings, which you must return to Him for your sin, in a small box beside it. Then send the cart away and let it go where it may.

verses.latin: Et aspicite: si viae suae finium Bethsames ascenderit, ipse fecit nobis hoc malum grande: sin autem, minime, sciemus quia non manus eius tetigit nos, sed casu accidit.
verses.english: Watch closely: if it goes up the road towards Beth Shemesh, then it means He Himself has inflicted this great harm upon us. But if it does not, then we will know that His hand did not touch us, and it was merely an accident.

verses.latin: Fecerunt ergo viri sic: et tollentes duas bigas, quae lactabant vitulos, junxerunt ad carrum: vitulosque earum concluserunt domi.
verses.english: So the men did as they were told: they took two nursing cows and yoked them to the cart. Then they shut up their calves at home.

verses.latin: Et posuerunt arcam Domini super currum, et capsellam quae habebat mures aureos et similitudines anorum.
verses.english: They then placed the Ark of the Lord on the cart, along with the small box containing the golden mice and the likenesses of the tumors.

verses.latin: Ierunt autem vaccae per viam quae ducit Bethsames, et itinere uno gradiebantur, et ululantes ibant: et non declinabant neque ad dextram neque ad sinistram. Sed et principes Philisthinorum sequebantur usque ad fines Bethsames.
verses.english: The cows went straight along the road leading to Beth Shemesh, traveling directly without turning either to the right or to the left, all the while lowing in distress—a supernatural sign. The Philistine rulers followed them all the way to the borders of Beth Shemesh.

verses.latin: Porro Bethsamitae metebant triticum in valle: et elevantes oculos suos, viderunt arcam, et gavisi sunt videntes.
verses.english: Now, the people of Beth Shemesh were reaping wheat in the valley. When they lifted their eyes and saw the Ark, they greatly rejoiced at the sight.

verses.latin: Et currus venit in agrum Iosue Bethsamitae, et stetit ibi. Erat autem ibi lapis magnus. Et conciderunt ligna currus, et vaccas imposuerunt super ea holocaustum Domino.
verses.english: The cart came into the field of Joshua, a man from Beth Shemesh, and stopped there. There was a large stone in that place. So they chopped up the wood of the cart and offered the cows upon it as a burnt offering to the Lord.

verses.latin: Levitae autem deposuerunt arcam Domini, et capsellam quae erat juxta illam, in qua erant vasa aurea: et posuerunt super lapidem magnum. Viri vero Bethsamitae obtulerunt holocausta, et immolaverunt victimas in die illa Domino.
verses.english: The Levites then took down the Ark of the Lord and the small box that was next to it, which contained the golden offerings. They placed these upon the large stone. The men of Beth Shemesh, for their part, offered burnt offerings and sacrificed other victims to the Lord on that day.

verses.latin: Quod videntes quinque principes Philisthinorum, reversi sunt in Accaron in die illa.
verses.english: After witnessing all of this, the five Philistine rulers returned to Ekron that same day.

verses.latin: Hi sunt autem anni aurei quos reddiderunt Philisthim pro peccato Domino: Azotus unum, Gaza unum, Ascalon unum, Geth unum, Accaron unum.
verses.english: These are the golden tumors which the Philistines offered to the Lord as a guilt offering for their sin: one for Ashdod, one for Gaza, one for Ashkelon, one for Gath, and one for Ekron.

verses.latin: Et mures aureos secundum numerum pagorum Philisthinorum, quinque provinciarum, ab urbe murata usque ad villam quae est absque muro, et usque ad lapidem magnum, super quem posuerunt arcam Domini, qui erat in agro Iosue Bethsamitae.
verses.english: And there were golden mice matching the number of all the Philistine towns across the five territories, from the walled cities down to the smallest unwalled villages. This includes the great stone where they placed the Ark of the Lord, which is in the field of Joshua, a man from Beth Shemesh.

verses.latin: Percussit autem de viris Bethsamitibus, quia viderant arcam Domini: et percussit de populo septuaginta viros, et quinquaginta millia plebis. Et luxit populus, eo quod percussisset Dominus plebem plaga magna.
verses.english: But the Lord struck down some of the men of Beth Shemesh because they had looked irreverently into the Ark of the Lord. He struck seventy men among the people, and fifty thousand of the common people. The people mourned greatly because the Lord had struck them with such a severe blow.

verses.latin: Et dixerunt viri Bethsamitae: Quis poterit stare in conspectu Domini Dei sancti? Et ad quem ascendet a nobis?
verses.english: The men of Beth Shemesh asked, 'Who can stand in the presence of the Lord, the holy God? And to whom shall this Ark ascend from us now?' —meaning, 'Who can take it away from us?'

verses.latin: Miserunt ergo nuncios ad habitatores Cariathiarim dicentes: Adduxerunt Philisthim arcam Domini, descendite, et reducite eam ad vos.
verses.english: So they sent messengers to the inhabitants of Kirjath Jearim, saying, 'The Philistines have brought back the Ark of the Lord. Come down and take it up to your city.'

verses.latin: Factum est autem septem diebus arca Domini in terra Philisthinorum.
verses.english: The Ark of the Lord had been in the land of the Philistines for seven full days.

verses.latin: Et vocaverunt Philisthim sacerdotes et divinos dicentes: Quid faciemus de arca Domini? indicite nobis quo modo remittamus eam in locum suum.
verses.english: Then the Philistines summoned their priests and soothsayers, asking, 'What shall we do with the Ark of the Lord? Tell us how we should send it back to its own place.'

verses.latin: Qui responderunt: Si remittitis arcam Dei Israel, nolite dimittere eam vacuam, sed quod debetis pro peccato reddite illi: et tunc curabimini, et scietis quare non recedat manus ejus a vobis.
verses.english: They responded, 'If you return the Ark of the God of Israel, you must not send it back empty. Instead, you must give Him a guilt offering for the sin you have committed. Then you will be healed, and you will understand why His hand has not stopped afflicting you.'

verses.latin: Et dixerunt illi: Quod est delicti, quod reddere debemus ei? Qui responderunt: Juxta numerum principum Philisthinorum, quinque anos aureos, et quinque mures aureos: quia plaga una omnibus et principibus vestris est.
verses.english: The Philistines asked them, 'What is the nature of the guilt offering we owe Him?' They answered, 'According to the number of the Philistine rulers, you must offer five golden tumors and five golden mice. This is because the same plague has afflicted all of you and your rulers.'

verses.latin: Facietis ergo similitudines anorum vestrorum, et similitudines murium, qui demoliti sunt terram: et dabitis Deo Israel gloriam, si forte relevet manum suam a vobis, et a diis vestris, et a terra vestra.
verses.english: Therefore, you must make images resembling your tumors and images resembling the mice that have devastated your land. You must give glory to the God of Israel, hoping that He might lift His hand from you, from your gods, and from your land.

verses.latin: Quare aggravatis corda vestra, sicut aggravavit Ægyptus et Pharao corda sua? nonne postquam percussus est, tunc dimisit eos, et abierunt?
verses.english: Why would you harden your hearts, just as Egypt and Pharaoh hardened their hearts? Was it not after He struck them that Pharaoh finally released the Israelites, and they departed?

verses.latin: Nunc ergo arcam unam novam facite: et duo boves, quae non portant jugum, jungite ad currum, et reducite vitulos eorum domum a quibus separati fuerint.
verses.english: So now, prepare a new cart, and harness two milk cows that have never worn a yoke to the cart. Then take their calves away from them and bring the calves back home.

verses.latin: Tolliteque arcam Domini, et ponite in curru: et vasa aurea, quae pro peccato reddidistis illi, mittite in capsellam ad latus ejus: et dimittite eam ut vadat.
verses.english: Take the Ark of the Lord and place it on the cart. Put the golden offerings you have given Him as a guilt offering in a box beside it. Then release the cart and let it go on its own.

verses.latin: Et aspicite: si viae suae limite ascenderit per viam Bethsames, ipse fecit nobis hoc malum grande: sin autem, minime, sciemus quia nequaquam manus ejus tetigit nos, sed casu accidit.
verses.english: Watch closely: if the cart ascends along the road to Beth Shemesh by its own route, then He has indeed inflicted this great evil upon us. But if not, then we will know that His hand did not touch us, and this was merely a random misfortune.

verses.latin: Fecerunt ergo viri sic: et tollentes duas vaccas, quae lactabant vitulos, junxerunt ad currum, vitulosque earum concluserunt domi.
verses.english: So the men followed these instructions: they took two milk cows and hitched them to the cart, but they shut their calves back home.

verses.latin: Et posuerunt arcam Dei super currum, et capsellam quae habebat mures aureos et similitudines anorum.
verses.english: They placed the Ark of God upon the cart, along with the box containing the golden mice and the images of the tumors.

verses.latin: Itaque in directum pergebant vaccae per viam Bethsames, et itinere uno gradiebantur, et mugiebant declinantes neque ad dextram neque ad sinistram: Philisthinorum quoque principes sequebantur usque ad fines Bethsames.
verses.english: The cows walked straight along the road toward Beth Shemesh, staying on a single path. They continued moo-ing as they went, turning neither to the right nor to the left. The rulers of the Philistines followed behind them all the way to the border of Beth Shemesh.

verses.latin: Porro Bethsamitae metebant triticum in valle: et elevantes oculos suos, viderunt arcam, et gavisi sunt videntes.
verses.english: Now, the people of Beth Shemesh were harvesting wheat in the valley. When they lifted their eyes, they saw the Ark, and they rejoiced greatly at the sight.

verses.latin: Et currus venit in agrum Josue Bethsamitae, et stetit ibi. Erat autem ibi lapis magnus. Et conciderunt ligna currus, et vaccas imposuerunt super ignem holocaustum Domino.
verses.english: The cart arrived in the field belonging to Joshua of Beth Shemesh and stopped there. There was a large stone in that place. The people then chopped up the wood of the cart and offered the cows as a burnt offering to the Lord on the fire.

verses.latin: Levitae autem deposuerunt arcam Dei, et capsellam quae erat juxta illam, in qua erant vasa aurea: et posuerunt super lapidem illum magnum. Viri vero Bethsamitae obtulerunt holocaustum et immolaverunt victimas in die illa Domino.
verses.english: The Levites carefully took down the Ark of God, and the box that was beside it, in which were the golden vessels; and they placed them on that great stone. The men of Beth Shemesh then offered burnt offerings and sacrificed other sacrifices to the Lord on that day.

verses.latin: Quo viso, quinque principes Philisthinorum reversi sunt in Accaron in die illa.
verses.english: After seeing all of this, the five rulers of the Philistines returned to Ekron that same day.

verses.latin: Hi sunt autem anni aurei, quos reddiderunt Philisthim pro peccato Domino: Azotus unum, Gaza unum, Ascalon unum, Geth unum, Accaron unum.
verses.english: These are the golden tumors that the Philistines rendered to the Lord as a guilt offering for their sin: one from Ashdod, one from Gaza, one from Ashkelon, one from Gath, and one from Ekron.

verses.latin: Et mures aurei secundum numerum urbium Philisthinorum, quinque provinciarum, ab urbe murata usque ad villam quae absque muro est, et usque ad lapidem magnum, super quem posuerunt arcam Domini, quae erat in agro Josue Bethsamitae.
