verses.latin: Saul autem et viri Israel congregati venerunt in vallem terebinthi, et instruxerunt aciem ad pugnam contra Philisthim.
verses.english: Saul and the men of Israel also gathered. They came to the Valley of Terebinth and arranged their battle lines, preparing to fight against the Philistines.

verses.latin: Et Philisthim stabant super montem ex hac parte, et Israel stabat super montem ex altera parte: vallisque erat inter eos.
verses.english: The Philistines stood on a mountain on one side, and the Israelites stood on a mountain on the other side, with a valley separating them.

verses.latin: Et egressus est vir spurius de castris Philisthinorum nomine Goliath, de Geth, altitudinis sex cubitorum et palmi.
verses.english: Then a special champion warrior came out of the Philistine camp. His name was Goliath, and he was from the city of Gath. He was an enormous man, measuring six cubits and a palm in height—a massive giant.

verses.latin: Et cassis ærea erat in capite ejus, et lorica squamata induebatur ærea appendens quinque millia siclos æris:
verses.english: He had a bronze helmet on his head, and he wore a coat of scale-armor made of bronze, which weighed five thousand shekels of bronze.

verses.latin: Et ocreas æreas habebat in cruribus, et clypeus æreus tegebat humeros ejus.
verses.english: He wore bronze greaves on his legs, and a bronze buckler shield was on his shoulders.

verses.latin: Et hasta ejus sicut liciatorium texentium: et ferrum hastæ ejus sexcentos siclos habebat ferri: et armiger ejus antecedebat eum.
verses.english: The shaft of his spear was like a weaver’s beam, and the iron head of his spear weighed six hundred shekels of iron. His shield-bearer walked ahead of him.

verses.latin: Stansque clamabat adversus acies Israel, et dixit eis: Quare venistis parati ad prælium? numquid ego non sum Philisthinus, et vos servi Saul? Eligite ex vobis virum, et descendat ad singulare certamen.
verses.english: Goliath stood and shouted to the Israelite battle lines, saying, “Why have you come out to prepare for battle? Am I not a Philistine, and are you not servants of Saul? Choose a man from among yourselves to come down and fight me in single combat.”

verses.latin: Si poterit ergo pugnare mecum, et percusserit me, nos servi erimus vobis: si autem ego prævaluero, et percussero eum, vos servi eritis nobis, et servietis nobis.
verses.english: He continued, “If he can fight against me and defeat me, then we will be your servants. But if I overcome him and defeat him, then you will be our servants and serve us.”

verses.latin: Et addidit Philisthinus: Ego exprobravi agminibus Israel hodie: Date mihi virum, et simul congrediamur.
verses.english: The Philistine also added, “I have openly defied the Israelite armies today! Give me a man, and let us fight each other!”

verses.latin: Audivit autem Saul et universus Israel sermones Philisthini hujus, et extimuerunt, et vehementer pertimuerunt.
verses.english: When Saul and all Israel heard these words from the Philistine, they were terrified, and they greatly feared him.

verses.latin: David autem erat filius viri Ephratæi de Bethlehem Juda, cujus nomen erat Isai, et habebat octo filios: et ipse erat senex, et grandævus inter viros.
verses.english: Now David was the son of an Ephrathite man from Bethlehem in Judah, whose name was Jesse. Jesse had eight sons, and he himself was an old man, advanced in years among men.

verses.latin: Et abierant tres filii ejus majores natu cum Saul ad prælium: et nomina eorum: Eliab primogenitus, et secundus Abinadab, tertius Samma.
verses.english: Jesse’s three oldest sons had gone with Saul to the battle. Their names were Eliab, the firstborn; Abinadab, the second; and Shamma, the third.

verses.latin: David autem erat minimus. Tribus ergo majoribus natu secutis Saul,
verses.english: David was the youngest. So while the three oldest sons followed Saul to battle,

verses.latin: David abierat, et reversus fuerat a Saul, ut pasceret gregem patris sui in Bethlehem.
verses.english: David had left the military service and returned from Saul’s camp to shepherd his father’s flock in Bethlehem.

verses.latin: Procedebat ergo Philisthinus mane et vespere, et stabat quadraginta diebus.
verses.english: The Philistine champion, Goliath, would come forward every morning and evening. He took his stand and issued his challenge for forty days.

verses.latin: Dixit autem Isai ad David filium suum: Sume fratribus tuis ephah polentæ hujus, et decem panes, et affer velociter in castra ad fratres tuos.
verses.english: Then Jesse said to his son David, “Take this ephah of roasted grain and these ten loaves of bread for your brothers. Hurry and bring them to your brothers in the camp.”

verses.latin: Et decem formellas casei has deferes ad tribunum, et fratres tuos visitabis, si recte agant, et quæ agant, discito.
verses.english: He continued, “Also, take these ten cheeses to the captain. See how your brothers are doing, and bring back a report of their welfare and what is happening there.”

verses.latin: Saul autem, et illi, et omnes filii Israel, erant in valle terebinthi, pugnantes adversum Philisthim.
verses.english: Now Saul, and Jesse's sons, and all the men of Israel, were in the Valley of Terebinth, fighting against the Philistines.

verses.latin: Igitur David de nocte consurgens, dimisit gregem patri suo cum custode: et onustus abiit sicut præceperat ei Isai. Et venit ad munitionem, ubi exercitus egressus ad pugnam vociferatus conflixerat.
verses.english: So David got up early in the morning. He left the flock with a keeper and, laden with supplies, went as Jesse had commanded him. He came to the camp, just as the army was going out to the battle line and shouting the battle cry.

verses.latin: Et instruxerat Israel et Philisthim aciem, acies contra aciem.
verses.english: Both Israel and the Philistines had drawn up their battle lines, arrayed against each other.

verses.latin: Et relinquens David vasa quæ suæ erant curæ sub manu custodis impedimentorum, cucurrit ad locum certaminis, et interrogabat fratres suos si omnia recte agerentur.
verses.english: David left his baggage, which was his responsibility, with the keeper of the supplies. He then ran to the battle lines and asked his brothers if everything was well with them.

verses.latin: Cumque adhuc ille loqueretur eis, apparuit vir spurius, ascendens Goliath nomen ejus, Philisthinus de Geth, de acie Philisthinorum: et loquebatur juxta eadem verba, et audivit David.
verses.english: While he was still speaking with them, the champion warrior appeared. It was Goliath by name, the Philistine from Gath, emerging from the Philistine battle line. He spoke the very same defiant words as before, and David heard them.

verses.latin: Omnes autem Israelitæ cum vidissent virum, fugerunt a facie ejus, timentes eum vehementer.
verses.english: All the Israelites who saw the man fled from his presence, fearing him greatly.

verses.latin: Et dixit unusquisque ad proximum suum: Numquid vidistis virum hunc qui ascendit? ad exprobrandum enim Israel ascendit. Virum ergo quem percusserit rex, divitiis magnis augebit, et filiam suam dabit ei, et domum patris ejus faciet absque tributo in Israel.
verses.english: And each one said to his neighbor, “Have you seen this man who has come up? He has come up to defy Israel. The king has promised to greatly enrich the man who defeats him, give him his daughter in marriage, and make his father’s house exempt from taxes in Israel.”

verses.latin: Et ait David ad viros qui stabant secum, dicens: Quis est hic Philisthinus incircumcisus, qui exprobravit exercitus Dei viventis?
verses.english: David then said to the men standing with him, “Who is this uncircumcised Philistine who dares to defy the armies of the living God?”

verses.latin: Et repetierunt ei populus sermonem juxta id quod dixerat: sic faciet regi viro qui percusserit eum.
verses.english: The people repeated the same words to him, saying, “This is what the king will do for the man who defeats him.”

verses.latin: Audivit autem Eliab frater ejus major natu loquentem ipsum ad alios, et iratus est furor ejus in David, et ait: Quare venisti huc? aut quare remisisti pauculas oves illas in deserto? Ego scio superbiam tuam, et nequitiam cordis tui: quia ut videres prælium, venisti.
verses.english: Now Eliab, his oldest brother, heard him speaking to the others. Eliab’s anger burned against David, and he said, “Why have you come down here? And with whom have you left those few sheep in the wilderness? I know your pride and the evil intention of your heart, for you have come down only to see the battle!”

verses.latin: Et ait David: Quid feci? numquid non verbum est?
verses.english: David replied, “What have I done now? Was it not just a question?”

verses.latin: Et declinavit ab eo, alterum quærens: et locutus est secundum idem verbum. Et respondit ei populus juxta priorem sermonem.
verses.english: He turned away from Eliab and asked another man. He spoke according to the same question, and the people answered him as they had before.

verses.latin: Et audita sunt verba quæ locutus est David, et nunciaverunt Sauli. Cumque audisset, accersivit eum.
verses.english: When David’s words were heard, they were reported to Saul. And when Saul heard about them, he sent for David.

verses.latin: Et ait David ad Saul: Non sit ultra inædificet cor cujuspiam: ego servus tuus vadam, et pugnabo adversus Philisthinum hunc.
verses.english: David said to Saul, “Let no man’s courage fail because of this giant. I, your servant, will go and fight against this Philistine.”

verses.latin: Et ait Saul ad David: Non vales resistere Philisthino huic, nec pugnare contra eum: quia puer es, et iste vir bellator ab adolescentia sua.
verses.english: Saul said to David, “You are not strong enough to stand against this Philistine or fight against him. You are just a youth, while he has been a warrior since his adolescence.”

verses.latin: Dixitque David ad Saul: Pastor tuus eram gregis patris mei, et cum venisset leo vel ursus, et rapuisset arietem de medio gregis,
verses.english: David replied to Saul, “I was my father’s shepherd of the flock. When a lion or a bear came and snatched a lamb from the middle of the flock,

verses.latin: et persecutus essem, et percussem, eruens de ore ejus: et si consurrexisset contra me, arripuissem palatum ejus, et percussem, atque interfecissem eum.
verses.english: I pursued it, attacked it, and rescued the lamb from its mouth. If it rose up against me, I would grab its jaw, strike it, and kill it.

verses.latin: Nam et leonem, et ursum ego occidi: et erit Philisthinus hic incircumcisus, quasi unus ex eis. Vadat et auferat exprobationem de Israel: quia quis est hic incircumcisus, qui audax est maledicere exercitum Dei viventis?
verses.english: Indeed, I have killed both a lion and a bear. This uncircumcised Philistine will be like one of them! Let him go and take away the defiance from Israel, because who is this uncircumcised man who dares to curse the army of the living God?”

verses.latin: Et addidit David: Dominus qui eripuit me de manu leonis, et de manu ursi, ipse me eruet de manu Philisthini hujus. Et ait Saul ad David: Vade, et Dominus sit tecum.
verses.english: David also added, “The Lord, who rescued me from the paw of the lion and from the paw of the bear, He Himself will rescue me from the hand of this Philistine.” And Saul said to David, “Go, and may the Lord be with you.”

verses.latin: Et induit Saul David vestimentis suis, et clypeum æreum posuit in capite ejus, et induit eum lorica.
verses.english: Then Saul dressed David in his own armor. He placed a bronze helmet on David’s head and clothed him with a coat of mail.

verses.latin: Accinctus ergo David gladio ejus super vestem suam, cœpit probare si posset incedere, quia nunquam usum habuerat: et dixit David ad Saul: Non possum sic incedere, quia non sum usus. Et deposuit ea.
verses.english: David buckled Saul’s sword over his own clothes and tried to walk, but he found he could not, because he had never worn such things before. So David said to Saul, “I cannot walk in these, for I am not accustomed to them.” And he took them off.

verses.latin: Et tulit baculum suum, quem semper habebat in manu: et elegit sibi quinque expedite lapides de torrente, et posuit eos in sacculo pastorali, quem habebat secum, et fundam manibus: et sic processit adversum Philisthinum.
verses.english: Then he took his staff, which he always carried in his hand. He chose five smooth stones from the stream bed and put them in his shepherd’s bag, which he had with him, and his sling was in his hand. And so he went forward against the Philistine.

verses.latin: Factum est autem, cum conpletus esset sermo, Saul ad David, anima Jonathæ conglutinata est animæ David, et dilexit eum Jonathan quasi animam suam.
verses.english: It came to pass that when David finished speaking with Saul, Jonathan’s soul was bound to David’s soul, and Jonathan loved him as his own soul.

verses.latin: Et tulit eum Saul in die illa, et non eum ultra redire permisit in domum patris sui.
verses.english: Saul took David into his service that day and no longer allowed him to return to his father’s house.

verses.latin: Percussit igitur Jonathan et David fœdus amicitiae: amabat enim illum quasi animam suam.
verses.english: So Jonathan and David made a covenant of friendship, for Jonathan loved David as his own soul.

verses.latin: Et expoliavit se Jonathan tunica qua erat vestitus, et dedit eam David, et reliqua vestimenta sua, usque ad gladium et arcum, et balteum.
verses.english: And Jonathan took off the cloak he was wearing and gave it to David, along with his other garments, even his sword, bow, and belt.

verses.latin: Egrediebatur quoque David ad omnia quæcumque Saul mittebat eum, et prudenter se habebat: constituitque eum Saul super viros belli, et acceptus erat in oculis universi populi, et in oculis servorum Saul.
verses.english: Moreover, David went out wherever Saul sent him, and he acted wisely. So Saul placed him over the men of war, and he was accepted in the eyes of all the people, and in the eyes of Saul’s servants.

verses.latin: Cum reverteretur autem David post cæsum Philistæum, egredientes mulieres de cunctis urbibus Israël cantabant choris, lætantes in occursum Saul regis, tympanis et organis.
verses.english: When David returned after killing the Philistine, the women came out from all the cities of Israel, singing in choruses and rejoicing to meet King Saul, with tambourines and musical instruments.

verses.latin: Et cantabant mulieres ludentes, atque dicentes: Percussit Saul mille, et David decem millia.
verses.english: And the women sang playfully, saying: 'Saul has struck down a thousand, and David ten thousand!'

verses.latin: Iratus est autem Saul nimis, et displicuit ei sermo iste: et dixit: Decem millia dederunt David, et mihi dederunt mille: quid ultra est ut habeat, nisi solum regnum?
verses.english: But Saul was exceedingly angry, and this saying displeased him. And he said: 'They have given David ten thousand, and to me they have given only a thousand. What more is left for him to have, except the kingdom itself?'

verses.latin: Suspicabatur ergo Saul David ex die illa et deinceps.
verses.english: Therefore, Saul suspected David from that day forward.

verses.latin: Post diem autem alterum arripuit spiritus Domini malus Saul, et prophetabat in medio domus suæ: David autem psallebat manu sua sicut per singulos dies: et lancea erat in manu Saul.
verses.english: But on the next day, an evil spirit from the Lord seized Saul, and he raved inside his house. David, meanwhile, played the lyre with his hand as he did every day, and a spear was in Saul’s hand.

verses.latin: Et misit Saul lanceam, cogitans, atque dicens: Percutiam David, et murum: et declinavit David a facie ejus secundo.
verses.english: And Saul threw the spear, thinking and saying: 'I will pin David to the wall!' But David dodged away from him twice.

verses.latin: Et timuit Saul David, eo quod Dominus esset cum eo, et a Saul recessisset.
verses.english: And Saul feared David, because the Lord was with him, and had departed from Saul.

verses.latin: Removit ergo eum Saul a se, et fecit eum tribunum et præfectum super mille viros: et egrediebatur et intrabat in conspectu populi.
verses.english: Therefore Saul removed him from his presence and made him a tribune and commander over a thousand men. And David went out and came in before the people.

verses.latin: In omnibus quoque viis suis David prudenter se habebat, et Dominus erat cum eo.
verses.english: In all his ways, David conducted himself wisely, and the Lord was with him.

verses.latin: Vidit itaque Saul quod prudenter se haberet vehementer, et cœpit eum formidare.
verses.english: So Saul saw that David conducted himself very wisely, and he began to fear him greatly.

verses.latin: Universus autem Israël et Juda diligebat David, quoniam ipse ingrediebatur et egrediebatur in conspectu eorum.
verses.english: But all Israel and Judah loved David, because he went out and came in before them.

verses.latin: Dixitque Saul ad David: Ecce filia mea major Merob, ipsam dabo tibi uxorem: tantummodo esto vir fortis, et prælia bella Domini. Saul autem cogitabat dicens: Non sit manus mea in eo, sed sit super eum manus Philistim.
verses.english: Then Saul said to David: 'Behold, my elder daughter Merob, I will give her to you as a wife. Only be a strong man and fight the Lord’s battles.' Saul, however, was thinking, saying: 'Let not my hand be against him, but let the hand of the Philistines be against him.'

verses.latin: Et dixit David ad Saul: Quis ego sum? aut quæ est vita mea? aut quæ est cognatio patris mei in Israël, ut fiam gener regis?
verses.english: And David said to Saul: 'Who am I? Or what is my life? Or what is my father’s family in Israel, that I should become the king’s son-in-law?'

verses.latin: Factum est autem in tempore quo deberet Merob filia Saul dari David, ut daretur Hadrieli Molathitæ uxorem.
verses.english: But it came to pass that at the time when Merob, Saul’s daughter, should have been given to David, she was instead given to Hadriel the Meholathite as his wife.

verses.latin: Dilexit autem Michol filia Saul altera David. Et nuntiatum est Saul, et placuit ei.
verses.english: Now Michol, Saul’s other daughter, loved David. And it was reported to Saul, and it pleased him.

verses.latin: Et dixit Saul: Dabo eam illi, ut sit ei in scandalum, et ut sit super eum manus Philistim. Dixit ergo Saul ad David: In duobus secundis gener meus eris.
verses.english: And Saul said: 'I will give her to him, that she may be a snare to him, and that the hand of the Philistines may be against him.' So Saul said to David: 'You shall be my son-in-law a second time!'

verses.latin: Et præcepit Saul servis suis: Loquimini David seorsum, dicentes: Ecce rex diligit te, et omnes servi ejus amant te: nunc ergo gener regis esse potes.
verses.english: And Saul commanded his servants: 'Speak to David in secret, saying: "Behold, the king loves you, and all his servants love you. Now therefore, you can become the king’s son-in-law!"'

verses.latin: Et locuti sunt servi Saul verba hæc in auribus David. Et dixit David: Num vobis parvum videtur generum esse regis? ego autem sum vir pauper et tenuis.
verses.english: And Saul’s servants spoke these words in David’s ears. And David said: 'Does it seem a small thing to you to be the king’s son-in-law? Yet I am a poor and humble man.'

verses.latin: Et renuntiaverunt servi Saul ei, dicentes: Hæc locutus est David.
verses.english: And Saul’s servants reported to him, saying: 'This is what David has said.'

verses.latin: Et ait Saul: Sic loquamini ad David: Non quærit rex munera, nisi tantum centum præputia Philistim, ut fiat ultio de inimicis regis. Porro Saul cogitabat tradere David in manus Philistim.
verses.english: And Saul said: 'Speak thus to David: "The king desires no dowry except one hundred foreskins of the Philistines, so that there may be vengeance against the king’s enemies."' But Saul was thinking to deliver David into the hands of the Philistines.

verses.latin: Cumque renuntiassent servi ejus David verba quæ dixerat Saul, placuit sermo in oculis David ut fieret gener regis. Et non transierant dies.
verses.english: When his servants reported to David the words that Saul had spoken, the offer pleased David, so that he might become the king’s son-in-law. And the days appointed for the dowry had not yet passed.

verses.latin: Et surrexit David, et abiit cum viris suis, et percussit de Philistim ducentos viros, et attulit præputia eorum, et adnumeravit ea regi, ut esset gener regis. Dedit itaque ei Saul Michol filiam suam uxorem.
verses.english: So David arose and went with his men, and he struck down two hundred men from the Philistines. And he brought their foreskins and counted them out to the king, so that he might become the king’s son-in-law. Therefore, Saul gave him Michol his daughter as a wife.

verses.latin: Et vidit Saul et intellexit, quoniam Dominus esset cum David: et Michol filia Saul dilexit eum.
verses.english: And Saul saw and understood that the Lord was with David, and that Michol, Saul’s daughter, truly loved him.

verses.latin: Et addidit Saul timere David magis: et factus est Saul inimicus David cunctis diebus.
verses.english: And Saul increased his fear of David even more. And Saul became an enemy of David all his days.

verses.latin: Et egressi sunt principes Philistim ad pugnam: et ex quo egressi sunt, prudentius se habebat David super omnes servos Saul, et celebre factum est nomen ejus vehementer.
verses.english: And the princes of the Philistines went out to battle. And as often as they went out, David conducted himself more wisely than all of Saul’s servants, and his name became exceedingly famous.

verses.latin: Locutus est autem Saul ad Jonathan filium suum, et ad omnes servos suos, ut occiderent David.
verses.english: Now King Saul spoke to his son Jonathan and to all his personal attendants, giving them orders to kill David.

verses.latin: Porro Jonathan filius Saul diligebat David valde: et nuntiavit Jonathan David, dicens: Quærit Saul pater meus te occidere: cave ergo tibi mane, et manes in abscondito, et celaris.
verses.english: But Jonathan, King Saul’s son, truly loved David. So Jonathan told David, saying, 'My father Saul is trying to kill you. So be careful tomorrow morning. You must stay hidden and conceal yourself.

verses.latin: Et ego egressus stabo juxta patrem meum in agro, ubicumque fuerit: et ego loquar de te ad patrem meum, et quodcumque videro, nuntiabo tibi.
verses.english: I will go out and stand with my father in the field where you are hiding. I will speak to my father about you, and whatever I find out, I will tell you.'

verses.latin: Locutus est ergo Jonathan de David bona ad Saul patrem suum: dixitque ad eum: Ne peccet rex in servum suum David, quia non peccavit tibi: et opera ejus bona sunt tibi valde.
verses.english: So Jonathan spoke good things about David to his father Saul. He said to the king, 'Let not the king sin against his servant David, because he has not sinned against you. In fact, his actions have been very beneficial to you.

verses.latin: Et posuit animam suam in manu sua, et percussit Philisthæum, et fecit Dominus salutem magnam universo Israeli: vidisti et lætatus es: quare ergo peccas in sanguine innoxio, interficiendo David, qui est absque culpa?
verses.english: He risked his own life and struck down the Philistine giant, Goliath. Through him, the Lord granted a great victory to all Israel. You saw it and rejoiced. Why then would you sin by shedding innocent blood, by killing David, who is without fault?'

verses.latin: Audiens autem Saul vocem Jonathan, juravit: Vivit Dominus, si occidetur.
verses.english: When Saul heard Jonathan’s words, he swore an oath, saying, 'As the Lord lives, David will not be killed.'

verses.latin: Et vocavit Jonathan David, et nuntiavit ei omnes sermones istos: et introduxit Jonathan David ad Saul, et fuit ante eum, sicut et heri et nudiustertius.
verses.english: So Jonathan called David and told him all these things. Then Jonathan brought David to Saul, and David was in Saul’s presence again, just as he had been before, for the past several days.

verses.latin: Rursumque inchoatum est bellum: et egressus David pugnavit adversum Philisthæos: percussitque eos plaga magna, et fugerunt a facie ejus.
verses.english: Then war broke out again. David went out and fought against the Philistines. He struck them with a great defeat, and they fled from his presence.

verses.latin: Et factus est spiritus Domini malus in Saul, et sedebat in domo sua, et parabat lanceam: et David psallebat manu sua.
verses.english: But an evil spirit from the Lord came upon Saul while he was sitting in his house with his spear ready in his hand. David was playing music with his hand (the lyre).

verses.latin: Et conatus est Saul configere David lancea in pariete: et declinavit David a facie Saul, et lancea Saul percussit parietem: et David fugit, et salvatus est nocte illa.
verses.english: Saul tried to pin David to the wall with the spear. But David dodged Saul, and the spear struck the wall. David fled and escaped that very night.

verses.latin: Misit ergo Saul lictores suos in domum David, ut custodirent eum, et interficerent mane. Nuntiavit autem David Michol uxor sua, dicens: Nisi salvaveris te nocte hac, mane morieris.
verses.english: Saul sent his executioners to David’s house to keep watch over him and kill him in the morning. But David’s wife Michol told him, saying, 'Unless you save yourself tonight, tomorrow morning you will die.'

verses.latin: Deponentque Michol David per fenestram. Abiit itaque, et fugiit, et evasit.
verses.english: So Michol let David down through a window. He left immediately, fled, and escaped.

verses.latin: Tulit autem Michol statuam, et posuit super lectum, et pellem caprinam posuit ad caput ejus, et operuit sagulo.
verses.english: Now Michol took a household idol (a teraphim), placed it on the bed, put goat’s hair at its head, and covered it with a cloak.

verses.latin: Misit ergo Saul ministros suos ut raperent David, et responsum est: Ægrotat.
verses.english: When Saul sent his messengers to seize David, they were told, 'He is sick.'

verses.latin: Rursumque misit Saul nuntios ut viderent David, dicens: Afferte eum ad me in lecto, ut occidatur.
verses.english: Saul sent the messengers again to see David, saying, 'Bring him up to me on the bed, so that he may be killed.'

verses.latin: Cumque venissent ministri, ecce simulacrum erat in lecto, et pellis caprina ad caput ejus.
verses.english: When the messengers came in, behold, there was the idol on the bed, with the goat’s hair at its head.

verses.latin: Et ait Saul ad Michol: Quare sic illudisti mihi, et dimisisti inimicum meum, ut fugeret? Et respondit Michol ad Saul: Quia ipse locutus est mihi: Dimitte me, aut interficiam te.
verses.english: Then Saul said to Michol, 'Why have you deceived me in this way, and let my enemy escape?' Michol answered Saul, 'Because he himself threatened me, saying: 'Let me go, or I will kill you.''

verses.latin: David autem fugiens salvatus est, et venit ad Samuelem in Ramatha, et nuntiavit ei omnia quæ fecerat ei Saul: et abierunt ipse et Samuel, et manserunt in Najoth.
verses.english: So David fled and was saved. He came to Samuel in Ramatha and told him everything that Saul had done to him. Then he and Samuel went and stayed in Najoth.

verses.latin: Et nuntiatum est Saul, dicentibus ei: Ecce David in Najoth in Ramatha.
verses.english: It was reported to Saul, saying, 'Behold, David is in Najoth in Ramatha.'

verses.latin: Misit ergo Saul lictores, ut raperent David: qui cum vidissent cœtum prophetarum vaticinantium, et Samuelem stantem super eos, factus est spiritus Dei etiam super lictores Saul, et prophetare cœperunt.
verses.english: So Saul sent his executioners to seize David. When they saw the company of prophets prophesying, with Samuel standing as their leader, the Spirit of God came upon Saul’s executioners as well, and they too began to prophesy.

verses.latin: Nuntiatum est Sauli, qui misit et alios nuntios: et prophetarunt et illi. Iratusque Saul ultra, misit tertios nuntios: qui et ipsi prophetarunt.
verses.english: When this was reported to Saul, he sent other messengers, and they also began to prophesy. Even more angered, Saul sent a third group of messengers, and they too began to prophesy.

verses.latin: Abiit ergo et ipse in Ramatha, et venit usque ad puteum magnum, qui est in Socho, et interrogavit, dicens: In quo loco sunt Samuel et David? Dixitque ei: Ecce in Najoth in Ramatha.
verses.english: So Saul himself went to Ramatha and came as far as the great well that is in Socho. He asked, saying, 'Where are Samuel and David?' And he was told, 'Behold, they are in Najoth in Ramatha.'

verses.latin: Et abiit illo in Najoth in Ramatha, et factus est super eum spiritus Dei, et ambulabat vadens et prophetans, donec veniret in Najoth in Ramatha.
verses.english: And as he went on to Najoth in Ramatha, the Spirit of God came upon him too, and he walked on, prophesying, until he arrived in Najoth in Ramatha.

verses.latin: Et expoliavit se etiam ipse vestimentis suis, et prophetavit cum cæteris coram Samuele, et jacuit nudo corpore tota die illa et nocte. Unde et exivit proverbium: Num et Saul inter prophetas?
verses.english: He even stripped off his own garments and prophesied with the others before Samuel. He lay there unclothed for that entire day and night. That is why the proverb came about: 'Is Saul also among the prophets?'

verses.latin: Jonathan vero filius Saul diligebat David valde: et nuntiavit Jonathan David, dicens: Quaerit Saul pater meus occidere te: quapropter observa te, quaeso, mane: et manebis in abscondito, et celaberis.
verses.english: But Jonathan, King Saul’s son, loved David very much. So Jonathan secretly sent word to David, saying: “My father, King Saul, is seeking to kill you. Therefore, I beg you, be on your guard tomorrow morning. You must go into hiding, and remain concealed.”

verses.latin: Et ego egrediens stabo juxta patrem meum in agro, ubicumque fuerit: et ego loquar de te ad patrem meum, et quodcumque videro, nuntiabo tibi.
verses.english: “And I myself will go out and stand beside my father in the open field, wherever he may happen to be. I will speak to my father about you, and whatever I discover, I will report back to you immediately.”

verses.latin: Locutus est ergo Jonathan de David bona ad Saul patrem suum: dixitque ad eum: Ne peccet rex in servum suum David, quia non peccavit tibi: et opera ejus bona sunt tibi valde.
verses.english: So Jonathan spoke well of David to his father, King Saul. He pleaded with him, saying: “Let not the king commit a sin against his own faithful servant David. For David has committed no sin against you, and indeed, his deeds have been very beneficial to you.”

verses.latin: Et posuit animam suam in manu sua, et percussit Philisthaeum, et fecit Dominus salutem magnam universo Israeli: vidisti, et laetatus es: quare ergo peccas in sanguine innocentem, et interficis David, qui est absque culpa?
verses.english: “David risked his very life and went into battle, striking down the Philistine giant. By his hand, the Lord brought about a great victory for all of Israel. You saw it then, and you greatly rejoiced. Why then would you sin against innocent blood, and kill David, who is truly without fault?”

verses.latin: Audivit autem Saul vocem Jonathan: et juravit Saul: Vivit Dominus, si occidetur.
verses.english: King Saul listened to the earnest plea of Jonathan. And so King Saul swore an oath, declaring: “As the Lord lives, David shall not be put to death.”

verses.latin: Et vocavit Jonathan David, et nuntiavit ei omnes sermones istos: et introduxit Jonathan David ad Saul, et fuit ante eum sicut hesterna die et pridie.
verses.english: Then Jonathan called David, and told him all of these words. And Jonathan brought David to King Saul, and David remained in his presence, serving him just as he had done on previous days.

verses.latin: Motum est ergo bellum rursum: et egressus David pugnavit adversum Philisthaeos, percussitque eos plaga magna, et fugerunt a facie ejus.
verses.english: Then war broke out yet again. So David went out and fought against the Philistines, striking them down with such a devastating blow that they fled in terror from his presence.

verses.latin: Et factus est spiritus Domini malus in Saul, et sedebat in domo sua, et habebat lanceam: et David psallebat in manu sua.
verses.english: And then, again, an evil spirit from the Lord troubled King Saul. He was sitting in his house with his spear in his hand, while David was playing his lyre and singing hymns to soothe him.

verses.latin: Et quaesivit Saul configere David lancea in pariete: et declinavit David a facie Saul, et lancea Saul percussit parietem: et David fugit, et salvatus est nocte illa.
verses.english: King Saul sought to pin David to the wall with his spear. But David quickly moved away from Saul’s presence, and Saul’s spear struck the wall instead. David immediately fled, and he was saved from death that very night.

verses.latin: Misit ergo Saul satellites suos in domum David, ut custodirent eum, et interficerent mane. Quod cum nuntiasset Michol uxori David, dicens: Nisi salvaveris te nocte hac, cras morieris.
verses.english: So King Saul sent his messengers to David’s house to keep watch over him through the night, intending to kill him in the morning. David’s wife, Michal, secretly informed him, saying: “Unless you make your escape this very night, you will surely be dead by tomorrow.”

verses.latin: Deposuit ergo Michol David per fenestram: et abiit, et aufugit, et evadit.
verses.english: So Michal helped David escape by letting him down through a window. He immediately departed, fled for his life, and managed to escape.

verses.latin: Et tulit Michol statuam, et posuit super lectum, et capillos caprarum posuit ad caput ejus, et operuit eam vestimentis.
verses.english: Michal then took a household idol, a *teraphim*, and placed it on the bed. She put a network of goat hair at its head to mimic human hair, and then covered the idol with a garment to make it look like a sleeping person.

verses.latin: Misit ergo Saul ministros ut raperent David: et responsum est: Aegrotat.
verses.english: When King Saul sent messengers to seize David, they were given the answer: “He is sick in bed.”

verses.latin: Remisit quoque Saul nuntios ut viderent David, dicens: Afferte eum ad me in lecto suo, ut interficiatur.
verses.english: King Saul sent the messengers back to see David, commanding: “Bring him here to me, even in his bed, so that I may put him to death myself.”

verses.latin: Cumque venissent nuntii, ecce statua erat in lecto, et rete pilorum caprinorum ad caput ejus.
verses.english: But when the messengers arrived, behold, they found only the household idol lying on the bed, with the network of goat hair at its head.

verses.latin: Et dixit Saul ad Michol: Quare sic illudisti mihi, et dimisisti inimicum meum, ut fugeret? Et respondit Michol ad Saul: Quia ipse locutus est mihi: Dimitte me, alioquin interficiam te.
verses.english: King Saul then confronted Michal, saying: “Why have you so shamelessly deceived me and allowed my enemy to escape?” Michal answered Saul: “Because he threatened me directly, saying: ‘Let me go, or else I will kill you.’”

verses.latin: David autem fugiens salvatus est, et venit ad Samuelem in Ramatha, et nuntiavit ei omnia quae fecerat ei Saul: et abierunt ipse et Samuel, et morati sunt in Najoth in Ramatha.
verses.english: In the meantime, David, having fled for his life, was saved. He came to the prophet Samuel in Ramath, and told him everything that King Saul had done to him. Then David and Samuel went to Najoth in Ramath and stayed there together.

verses.latin: Et nuntiatum est Saul, dicens: Ecce David in Najoth in Ramatha.
verses.english: And it was reported to King Saul, saying: “Behold, David is in Najoth in Ramath.”

verses.latin: Misit ergo Saul nuntios ut raperent David: qui cum vidissent cœtum prophetarum vaticinantium, et Samuelem stantem super eos, factus est etiam spiritus Domini in nuntiis Saul, et prophetare cœperunt.
verses.english: So King Saul sent messengers to seize David. But when they arrived and saw the company of prophets engaged in prophetic utterance, with Samuel standing over them as their leader, the Spirit of the Lord also came upon King Saul’s messengers, and they too began to prophesy.

verses.latin: Nuntiatum est autem Saul, et misit alios nuntios: et prophetarunt et illi. Et rursum tertio misit Saul nuntios, qui et ipsi prophetarunt. Et iratus est Saul valde, et abiit et ipse in Ramatha.
verses.english: But when this was reported to King Saul, he sent yet another group of messengers. They also began to prophesy when they arrived. And a third time King Saul sent messengers, and they too began to prophesy. At this, King Saul became extremely angry, and he himself departed for Ramath.

verses.latin: Et venit usque ad puteum magnum, qui est in Socho: et interrogavit, dicens: In quo loco est Samuel et David? Dixitque ei unus: Ecce in Najoth in Ramatha.
verses.english: And he came as far as the great well that is in Socho. He then inquired, asking: “In what place are Samuel and David?” And one of the men there told him: “Behold, they are in Najoth, in Ramath.”

verses.latin: Et abiit illuc in Najoth in Ramatha: et factus est super eum etiam spiritus Domini, et ambulabat vadens et prophetabat, donec veniret in Najoth in Ramatha.
verses.english: So King Saul went there to Najoth in Ramath. And the Spirit of the Lord also came upon him. As he walked along the way, he continued prophesying until he reached Najoth in Ramath.

verses.latin: Et expoliavit se etiam ipse vestimentis suis, et prophetavit coram Samuele, et cecidit nudus tota die illa et nocte. Unde et proverbium exiit: Num et Saul inter prophetas?
verses.english: And he too stripped himself of his royal garments, and prophesied before Samuel. He lay there naked, prostrate on the ground, for that entire day and all through the night. This is why the proverb came into being: “Is Saul also counted among the prophets?”

verses.latin: Fugit autem David de Najoth, quæ est in Ramatha: venitque coram Jonathan, et dixit: Quid feci? aut quæ est iniquitas mea, et quod peccatum meum in patrem tuum, quia quærit animam meam?
verses.english: But David fled from Naioth, which is in Ramah. He then came before Jonathan and asked: "What have I done? What is my sin, and what is my iniquity against your father, that he is seeking my very life?"

verses.latin: Cui ille respondit: Absit a te hoc verbum: non morieris: neque enim faciet pater meus quicquam grande vel parvum, nisi prius indicaverit mihi: hunc ergo sermonem quare celavit me pater meus? non est hoc ita.
verses.english: Jonathan answered him: "Far be it from you to think that! You shall not die. For my father does nothing, whether great or small, without first revealing it to me. Why then would my father hide this matter from me? It is not as you think."

verses.latin: Et juravit rursum David, et ait: Scit quidem pater tuus quia inveni gratiam in oculis tuis, et ait: Non sciat hoc Jonathan, ne forte tristetur. Quinimmo vivit Dominus, et vivit anima tua, quia uno tantum gradu ego et mors.
verses.english: But David swore again and said: "Your father knows very well that I have found favor in your eyes. He said to himself, 'Jonathan must not know this, lest he be grieved.' Truly, as the Lord lives, and as your soul lives, there is only a step between me and death."

verses.latin: Et ait Jonathan ad David: Quodcumque dixerit tibi anima tua, faciam tibi.
verses.english: Jonathan then said to David: "Whatever your soul desires, I will do for you."

verses.latin: Dixit autem David ad Jonathan: Ecce calendæ sunt crastino, et ego non possum comedere cum rege:
verses.english: David said to Jonathan: "Behold, tomorrow is the new moon festival, and I cannot eat with the king. I must be absent."

verses.latin: sed dimitte me, ut abscondar in agro usque ad vesperam diei tertiæ.
verses.english: "Therefore, let me go, so that I may hide in the field until the evening of the third day."

verses.latin: Si requisierit me pater tuus, respondebis ei: Rogavit me David, ut iret in Bethlehem civitatem suam: quia sollemnes sunt ibi sacrificiæ universis cognatis suis.
verses.english: "If your father asks for me, you shall answer him: 'David earnestly requested me to let him go to Bethlehem, his own city, because there is a solemn sacrifice there for all his relatives.'"

verses.latin: Si dixerit: Bene est: pax erit servo tuo: si autem fuerit iratus, scito quia completa est malitia ejus.
verses.english: "If he says, 'It is well,' then your servant is safe. But if he becomes angry, know for certain that his evil intent is fixed."

verses.latin: Fac ergo misercordiam in servum tuum, quoniam inierras me servum tuum in fœdus Domini tecum. Si quam est in me iniquitas, interfice me tu: et ad patrem tuum ne introducas me.
verses.english: "Therefore, deal mercifully with your servant, for you have brought me, your servant, into a covenant of the Lord with you. If there is any iniquity in me, kill me yourself; do not bring me to your father."

verses.latin: Et ait illi Jonathan: Absit a te hoc: quoniam si certo cognovero malum esse completum a patre meo ut veniat super te, ego indicabo tibi.
verses.english: Jonathan said to him: "Far be it from you to think that! For if I should certainly know that evil has been determined by my father to come upon you, I myself will tell you."

verses.latin: Et ait David ad Jonathan: Quis indicabit mihi si quid forte responderit tibi pater tuus durum?
verses.english: David said to Jonathan: "Who will inform me if your father answers you harshly?"

verses.latin: Et ait Jonathan ad David: Veni, et egrediamur foras in agrum. Cumque exissent ambo in agrum,
verses.english: Jonathan said to David: "Come, let us go out into the field." So both of them went out into the field.

verses.latin: et ait Jonathan ad David: Dominus Deus Israel testis sit, si investigando perscrutatus fuero patrem meum, et si quid boni fuerit super David, et non statim misero ad te et revelavero tibi.
verses.english: Then Jonathan said to David: "May the Lord, the God of Israel, be a witness! I will diligently question my father. If there is anything good concerning David, I will surely send word to you and reveal it to you without delay."

verses.latin: Hæc loquor et non in perpetuum morieris:
verses.english: "This I say: may you never perish." —meaning, may your life and lineage be preserved.

verses.latin: aut si interierit domus mea, cum affulserit Dominus mala super terram in omnibus inimicis David,
verses.english: "Or if my house perishes, when the Lord has brought evil upon the earth against all the enemies of David,"

verses.latin: abjiciat Jonathan animam suam ab oculis tuis in sempiternum: sed et tu facies cum servo tuo misericordiam Domini in sempiternum, et non interficies me.
verses.english: "may Jonathan himself be cast off from your sight forever. But you also shall show the Lord's mercy to your servant forever, and you shall not kill me."

verses.latin: Adjecit ergo Jonathan jurare David, eo quod diligeret illum: sicut enim animam suam, ita diligebat eum.
verses.english: Jonathan therefore made David swear again, because he loved him; for he loved him as his own soul.

verses.latin: Dixitque illi Jonathan: Cras calendæ sunt, et requireris.
verses.english: Jonathan also said to him: "Tomorrow is the new moon festival, and you will be missed."

verses.latin: Desiderabitur enim sessio tua. Et tertia die festinabis, et venies ad locum ubi celabas te in die operis, et sedebis juxta lapidem cui vocabulum est Ezel.
verses.english: "Indeed, your seat will be empty. On the third day, you must hurry and come to the place where you hid yourself on the day of the appointed meeting, and you will sit by the stone whose name is Ezel."

verses.latin: Et ego tres sagittas jeciam juxta illud, quasi jacientis in signum.
verses.english: "And I will shoot three arrows beside it, as if I were shooting at a target."

verses.latin: Ecce, mittam puerum, dicens ei: Vade, et affer mihi sagittas. Si dixero puero: Ecce sagittæ intra te sunt, tolle eas, tu veni ad me: quia pax tibi est, et nihil est mali, vivit Dominus.
verses.english: "Behold, I will send a boy, saying to him, 'Go, fetch me the arrows.' If I say to the boy, 'Behold, the arrows are within reach of you, pick them up,' then you come to me. For there is peace for you, and no harm is intended, as the Lord lives."

verses.latin: Si autem sic locutus fuero puero: Ecce sagittæ ultra te sunt: vade velociter, quia dimisit te Dominus.
verses.english: "But if I speak thus to the boy: 'Behold, the arrows are beyond you,' then go quickly, because the Lord has sent you away."

verses.latin: De verbo autem hoc, quod locuti sumus ego et tu, sit Dominus inter me et te usque in sempiternum.
verses.english: "And concerning this word, which we have spoken, you and I, may the Lord be between me and you forever."

verses.latin: Itaque absconditus est David in agro: et lunæ novæ dies advenit, et sedit rex ad comedendum panem.
verses.english: So David hid himself in the field. When the new moon festival day came, the king sat down to eat bread.

verses.latin: Et sedit rex juxta consuetudinem suam super cathedram, quæ juxta parietem erat: surrexitque Jonathan, et sedit Abner a latere Saul, et vacuus apparuit locus David.
verses.english: The king sat in his customary place, which was by the wall. Jonathan rose, and Abner sat at Saul's side, but David's place appeared empty.

verses.latin: Et non locutus est Saul quidquam in die illa, quia reputabat casum, ne forte mundus non esset, nec purificatus.
verses.english: And Saul said nothing on that day, because he supposed that something had happened by chance, that perhaps David was not ritually clean nor purified.

verses.latin: Cumque illuxisset dies secunda post kalendas, absens fuit David de mensa regis. Dixitque Saul ad Jonathan filium suum: Cur non venit filius Isai ad mensam nec heri nec hodie?
verses.english: But when the second day after the new moon festival dawned, David was still absent from the king's table. Saul then said to Jonathan, his son: "Why has the son of Jesse not come to the meal, neither yesterday nor today?"

verses.latin: Et respondit Jonathan Sauli: Rogavit me David, ut iret in Bethlehem.
verses.english: Jonathan answered Saul: "David earnestly requested me to let him go to Bethlehem."

verses.latin: Dixitque: Dimitte me, quoniam sacrificium familiare est in civitate, et ego jussus sum ab eo fratre meo: et nunc si inveni gratiam in oculis tuis, vadam cito, et videbo fratres meos. Ob hanc causam non venit ad mensam regis.
verses.english: "He said: 'Let me go, because there is a family sacrifice in the city, and my brother has commanded me to be there. So now, if I have found favor in your eyes, I will go quickly and see my brothers.' For this reason, he has not come to the king's table."

verses.latin: Et iratus est Saul contra Jonathan, et dixit ei: Fili mulieris virum ultra modum perversæ voluntatis, numquid ignoro quia diligis filium Isai in confusionem tuam et in confusionem ignominiæ matris tuæ?
verses.english: Then Saul became angry with Jonathan and said to him: "You son of a perverse and rebellious woman, do I not know that you love the son of Jesse to your own shame and to the shame and disgrace of your mother?"

verses.latin: Omnibus enim diebus, quibus moratur filius Isai super terram, non stabilieris tu neque regnum tuum. Nunc ergo mitte, et adduc eum ad me, quia filius mortis est.
verses.english: "For as long as the son of Jesse lives upon the earth, neither you nor your kingdom will be established. Now, therefore, send and bring him to me, for he is a son deserving of death."

verses.latin: Et respondens Jonathan Sauli patri suo, ait: Quare morietur? quid fecit?
verses.english: Jonathan answered Saul, his father, and said: "Why should he die? What has he done?"

verses.latin: Et levavit Saul hastam contra Jonathan ut percuteret eum. Et intellexit Jonathan quia completum est a patre suo ut interficeret David.
verses.english: Then Saul raised his spear against Jonathan to strike him. And Jonathan understood that his father was determined to kill David.

verses.latin: Et surrexit Jonathan a mensa in ira furoris, et non comedit in die secunda mensæ calendæ panem: contristatus est enim super David, eo quod confudisset eum pater suus.
verses.english: So Jonathan rose from the table in furious anger and did not eat bread on the second day of the new moon festival meal. For he was grieved for David, because his father had disgraced him.

verses.latin: Cumque illuxisset mane, venit Jonathan in agrum juxta sermonem David, et puer parvulus cum eo.
verses.english: When morning dawned, Jonathan came into the field according to David's word, and a small boy was with him.

verses.latin: Et dixit ad puerum suum: Vade, et affer mihi sagittas quas ego jacio. Cumque puer cucurrisset, alteram sagittas jecit ultra puerum.
verses.english: He said to his boy: "Go, fetch me the arrows that I shoot." As the boy ran, Jonathan shot an arrow beyond the boy.

verses.latin: Venit ergo puer ad locum sagittæ quam jacuerat Jonathan: et clamavit Jonathan post tergum pueri, et ait: Ecce sagitta ultra te est.
verses.english: So the boy came to the place of the arrow that Jonathan had shot. And Jonathan cried out after the boy's back, saying: "Behold, the arrow is beyond you!"

verses.latin: Et clamavit Jonathan post tergum pueri, dicens: Festina velociter, ne steteris. Collegit ergo puer Jonathan sagittas, et attulit domino suo.
verses.english: And Jonathan cried out after the boy's back, saying: "Hurry quickly, do not stand still!" So the boy of Jonathan gathered the arrows and brought them to his master.

verses.latin: Porro puer nihil prorsus sciebat: nisi Jonathan et David rem agebant.
verses.english: However, the boy knew absolutely nothing of the matter; only Jonathan and David understood the secret plan.

verses.latin: Dedit ergo Jonathan arma sua puero, et dixit ei: Vade, defer in civitatem.
verses.english: Then Jonathan gave his weapons to the boy and said to him: "Go, carry them into the city."

verses.latin: Venit autem David in Nobe ad Achimelech sacerdotem: et obstupuit Achimelech occursum David, et dixit ei: Quare tu solus, et nullus est tecum?
verses.english: David then arrived in Nob, where he met Ahimelech the priest. Ahimelech was surprised to see David and he asked him: 'Why are you alone? Is no one else with you?'

verses.latin: Et ait David ad Achimelech sacerdotem: Rex præcepit mihi sermonem, et dixit: Nemo sciat rem, pro qua ego sum missus, et quid tibi præcepi: et pueros abscondi in loco illo et illo.
verses.english: David responded to Ahimelech the priest, saying: 'The king has given me a secret order, and he said to me: “No one is to know about the mission I am on, or what I commanded you.” So I sent my young men to a certain place and told them to hide there.'

verses.latin: Nunc ergo si quid habes ad manum, da mihi, vel quinque panes, vel qualescumque reperies.
verses.english: Now, if you have any provisions on hand, please give me something. Even five loaves of bread would be enough, or whatever you can find.

verses.latin: Et respondens sacerdos ad David, ait: Non habeo panes profanos ad manum, sed tantum panem sanctum, si mundi sunt pueri tui, maxime a mulieribus.
verses.english: The priest answered David, saying: 'I don’t have any ordinary bread here. I only have the consecrated bread—the Bread of the Presence. You may have it only if your young men are ritually pure, especially if they have abstained from contact with women.'

verses.latin: Et respondit David sacerdoti, et dixit ei: Equidem si de uxore agitur, et si de mulieribus, continuimus nos ab heri et nudiustertius, quando egrediebamur, et fuerunt vasa puerorum sancta. Porro via hæc polluta est, sed et ipsa hodie sanctificabitur in vasis.
verses.english: David answered the priest, saying: 'Indeed, as for women, we have kept ourselves from them since yesterday and the day before, ever since we departed. My young men are ritually clean. Furthermore, even if this particular journey made us unclean, it will be made holy today by our commitment to holiness.'

verses.latin: Dedit ergo ei Achimelech panem propositionis, quoniam nullus erat alius panis ibi, absque pane propositionis, qui sublatus fuerat a facie Domini, ut poneretur panis calidus.
verses.english: So Achimelech gave him the Bread of the Presence, because there was no other bread there except for that Bread of the Presence, which had been removed from before the Lord so that fresh, hot bread could be put in its place.

verses.latin: Erat autem ibi vir de servis Saul, in die illa, intus in tabernaculo Domini, nomine Doëg Idumæus, pastor multorum camelorum Saul.
verses.english: Now, one of Saul’s servants happened to be there that day, confined in the tabernacle of the Lord. His name was Doëg the Idumaean, and he was in charge of Saul’s many camels.

verses.latin: Et ait David ad Achimelech: Si habes hic ad manum hastam vel gladium? quia gladium meum et arma mea non tuli mecum: sermo enim regis urguebat.
verses.english: David then said to Ahimelech: 'Do you have a spear or a sword here on hand? For I did not bring my sword or my weapons with me, because the king’s mission required haste.'

verses.latin: Et dixit sacerdos: Gladius Goliath Philisthæi, quem interfecisti in valle Terebinthi, est involutus pallio post ephod: si istum vis tollere, tolle: neque enim est alius hic, absque hoc. Et ait David: Non est alter similis illi: da mihi eum.
verses.english: The priest replied: 'The sword of Goliath the Philistine, whom you killed in the Valley of Elah, is here. It is wrapped in a cloth behind the ephod. If you want to take it, take it, for there is no other sword here except this one.' David then exclaimed: 'There is none like it! Give it to me!'

verses.latin: Surrexitque David, et fugit in die illa a facie Saul: et venit ad Achis regem Geth.
verses.english: So David rose and fled that day from Saul. He went to King Achis of Gath.

verses.latin: Dixeruntque servi Achis ad eum: Numquid non iste est David rex terræ? nonne huic cantabant per choros, dicentes: Percussit Saul mille, et David decem millia?
verses.english: King Achis’s servants said to him: 'Isn’t this David, the king of his land? Isn’t he the one people sang about in their dances, saying: 'Saul has struck down a thousand, and David ten thousand!''

verses.latin: Posuit autem David sermones istos in corde suo, et extimuit valde a facie Achis regis Geth.
verses.english: David took these words to heart and became very afraid of King Achis of Gath.

verses.latin: Commutavitque os suum coram eis, et collabebatur inter manus eorum: et impingebat in ostia portæ, et fluebant salivæ ejus in barbam.
verses.english: So he changed his behavior in front of them and pretended to be mad while in their hands. He scratched on the doors of the city gate, and his saliva ran down his beard.

verses.latin: Et ait Achis ad servos suos: Ecce vidistis virum insanum: quare adduxistis eum ad me?
verses.english: King Achis then said to his servants: 'Look, you can see this man is insane. Why have you brought him to me?'

verses.latin: An desunt nobis et insani, ut istum adduceretis? an iste ingredietur domum meam?
verses.english: 'Do we not have enough madmen of our own that you should bring this one to me? Is this fellow to enter my house?'

verses.latin: Egressus est ergo David inde, et fugit in speluncam Odollam. Quod cum audissent fratres ejus, et omnis domus patris ejus, descenderunt ad eum illuc.
verses.english: David therefore departed from there and fled to the cave of Adullam. When his brothers and all his father’s household heard about it, they went down to him there.

verses.latin: Et convenerunt ad eum omnes qui erant in angustia, et omni ære alieno oppressi, et amaro animo: et factus est eorum princeps: fueruntque cum eo quasi quadringenti viri.
verses.english: And everyone who was in distress, or overwhelmed by debt, or bitter in spirit, gathered to him. He became their leader, and about four hundred men were with him.

verses.latin: Et profectus est David inde in Maspha, quæ est Moab, et dixit regi Moab: Manere, obsecro, fac patrem meum et matrem meam apud vos, donec sciam quid faciat mihi Deus.
verses.english: David then went from there to Mizpah of Moab and said to the king of Moab: 'Please let my father and mother stay with you until I know what God will do for me.'

verses.latin: Et reliquit eos apud regem Moab: manseruntque apud eum cunctis diebus quibus David fuit in præsidio.
verses.english: And he left them with the king of Moab, and they stayed with him for all the days that David was in the stronghold.

verses.latin: Dixitque Gad propheta ad David: Noli manere in præsidio: proficiscere, et vade in terram Juda. Et profectus est David, et venit in saltum Hareth.
verses.english: Then Gad the prophet said to David: 'Do not stay in the stronghold. Depart and go into the land of Judah.' So David departed and went to the forest of Hereth.

verses.latin: Et audivit Saul quod manifestatus esset David, et viri qui erant cum eo, ipse autem morabatur in Gabaa, et sedebat in nemore, quod est in Rama, et lancea tenebat in manu sua, et universi servi ejus circumstabant eum.
verses.english: Saul heard that David and the men with him had been discovered. Saul himself was then staying in Gibeah, sitting under the tamarisk tree on the high place in Ramah, with his spear in his hand, and all his servants were standing around him.

verses.latin: Et ait Saul ad omnes servos suos, qui circumstabant eum: Audite nunc filii Jemini: numquid omnibus vobis dabit filius Isai agros et vineas, et universos vos faciet tribunos et centuriones?
verses.english: Saul then said to all his servants who stood around him: 'Listen now, you sons of Benjamin! Will the son of Jesse give all of you fields and vineyards? Will he make all of you commanders of a thousand and commanders of a hundred?'

verses.latin: Quoniam conjurastis omnes adversum me, et non est qui mihi renuntiet, cur inierit fœdus filius meus cum filio Isai? nec est qui misereatur mei vestrum, et annuntiet mihi: eo quod suscitavit filius meus servum meum adversum me insidiantem mihi usque hodie.
verses.english: 'For all of you have conspired against me, and no one tells me why my son has made a covenant with the son of Jesse. And there is no one among you who pities me or informs me that my son has stirred up my servant against me, to lie in wait for me, as is clear today.'

verses.latin: Respondens autem Doëg Idumæus, qui stabat juxta servos Saul, ait: Vidi filium Isai, venientem in Nobe, ad Achimelech filium Achitob sacerdotem:
verses.english: But Doëg the Idumaean, who was standing with Saul’s servants, answered and said: 'I saw the son of Jesse coming to Nob, to Ahimelech, the son of Ahitub the priest.'

verses.latin: Qui consuluit ei Dominum, et panes dedit illi, sed et gladium Goliath Philisthæi dedit ei.
verses.english: 'He consulted the Lord for him, and gave him bread, and also gave him the sword of Goliath the Philistine.'

verses.latin: Misit ergo rex ad Achimelech sacerdotem, filium Achitob, et ad universam domum patris ejus, sacerdotum qui erant in Nobe, qui omnes venerunt ad regem.
verses.english: So the king sent for Ahimelech the priest, the son of Ahitub, and for all the house of his father, the priests who were in Nob. They all came to the king.

verses.latin: Et ait Saul: Audi fili Achitob. Qui respondit: Ecce ego, domine.
verses.english: Saul then said: 'Listen, son of Ahitub!' He answered: 'Here I am, my lord.'

verses.latin: Et dixit ad eum Saul: Quare conjurastis adversum me, tu, et filius Isai? et dedisti ei panes, et gladium: et consuluit pro eo Deum, ut consurgeret adversum me insidiator usque hodie.
verses.english: And Saul said to him: 'Why have you conspired against me, you and the son of Jesse? You gave him bread and a sword, and you consulted God for him, so that he would rise up against me as an ambush, even to this very day.'

verses.latin: Et respondens Achimelech regi, ait: Et quis in omnibus servis tuis sicut David fidelis, et gener regis, et pergens ad imperium tuum, et honoratus in domo tua?
verses.english: Ahimelech answered the king, saying: 'And who among all your servants is as faithful as David, who is also the king’s son-in-law? He carries out your commands and is honored in your house.'

verses.latin: An hodie cœpi consulere pro eo Deum? Absit hoc a me: ne suspicetur rex in servum suum, nec in omnem domum patris mei: non enim scivit servus tuus quidquam ex omnibus his, vel minus vel plus.
verses.english: 'Did I only begin to consult God for him today? Far be it from me! Let not the king suspect anything against his servant, or against all the house of my father. For your servant knew nothing at all of this, neither more nor less.'

verses.latin: Et ait rex: Morte morieris, Achimelech, tu et omnis domus patris tui.
verses.english: And the king said: 'You shall surely die, Ahimelech, you and all the house of your father!'

verses.latin: Et dixit rex emissariis, qui circumstabant eum: Ite, et interficite sacerdotes Domini: quia manus eorum cum David est, et scientes quoniam fugerat, non indicaverunt mihi. Et noluerunt servi regis extendere manum suam in sacerdotes Domini.
verses.english: The king then said to the guards standing around him: 'Go, and kill the priests of the Lord! Because their hand is with David, and knowing that he had fled, they did not inform me.' But the king’s servants were unwilling to lay their hands on the priests of the Lord.

verses.latin: Et ait rex ad Doëg: Convertere tu, et interfice sacerdotes. Et conversus Doëg Idumæus, interfecit ipse sacerdotes: et trucidavit in die illa octoginta quinque viros, vestitos ephod lineo.
verses.english: Then the king said to Doëg: 'You turn and kill the priests!' And Doëg the Idumaean turned and himself killed the priests. He slaughtered on that day eighty-five men who wore the linen ephod.

verses.latin: Nobe autem civitatem sacerdotum percussit in ore gladii, viros, et mulieres, pueros, et lactentes, boves, et asinos, et oves, in ore gladii.
verses.english: And Nob, the city of the priests, he struck with the edge of the sword—men and women, children and infants, oxen, donkeys, and sheep—all by the edge of the sword.

verses.latin: Evasit autem unus filius Achimelech filii Achitob, cui nomen erat Abiathar, et fugit ad David.
verses.english: However, one son of Ahimelech, son of Ahitub, whose name was Abiathar, escaped and fled to David.

verses.latin: Et nuntiavit David quod interfecisset Saul sacerdotes Domini.
verses.english: And he reported to David that Saul had killed the priests of the Lord.

verses.latin: Et ait David ad Abiathar: Sciebam in die illa, quod cum Doëg Idumæus esset ibi, procul dubio nuntiaret Saul: ego sum reus omnium animarum domus patris tui.
verses.english: And David said to Abiathar: 'I knew on that day, when Doëg the Idumaean was there, that he would surely report it to Saul. I am responsible for the loss of all the lives in your father’s house.'

verses.latin: Mane mecum, ne timeas: quocumque enim perrexerit anima mea, illuc perget et anima tua mecum.
verses.english: 'Stay with me, do not be afraid. For wherever my life goes, your life will go with me.'

verses.latin: Et nuntiaverunt David, dicentes: Ecce Philisthæi pugnant adversum Ceila, et ipsi diripiunt areas.
verses.english: Then David was informed, saying: 'Look, the Philistines are fighting against Keilah, and they are plundering the threshing floors!'

verses.latin: Consuluit ergo David Dominum, dicens: Si vadam, et percutiam Philisthæos istos? Et dixit Dominus ad David: Vade, et percute Philisthæos, et salva Ceila.
verses.english: So David consulted the Lord, saying: 'Shall I go and strike down these Philistines?' And the Lord said to David: 'Go, strike down the Philistines, and save Keilah.'

verses.latin: Venit ergo David in Nobe ad Achimelech sacerdotem: et obstupuit Achimelech occursum David, et dixit ei: Quare tu solus, et nullus est tecum?
verses.english: David therefore came to Nob to see Achimelech, the high priest. Achimelech was startled when David arrived, and he said to him, 'Why are you all by yourself? Why is there no one with you?'

verses.latin: Et ait David ad Achimelech sacerdotem: Rex præcepit mihi sermonem, et dixit: Nemo sciat rem, propter quam a me missus es, et cujusmodi præcepta tibi dederim: nam et pueris nuntiari feci in illum et illum locum.
verses.english: David said to Achimelech the high priest, 'The king has given me a secret mission and told me: 'No one is to know about the mission I have sent you on, nor the instructions I have given you.' I have also arranged for my young men to meet me at a specified location.'

verses.latin: Nunc ergo si quid habes ad manum, da mihi saltem quinque panes, aut quoscumque repereris.
verses.english: Now then, if you have any food available, give me at least five loaves of bread, or whatever else you can find.

verses.latin: Et respondens sacerdos ad David, ait: Non habeo panes profanos ad manum, sed tantum panem sanctum: si mundi sunt pueri, maxime a mulieribus?
verses.english: The priest answered David, saying, 'I don't have any ordinary bread available, but only the holy showbread, which is consecrated to God. Are the young men pure, especially from having been with women?'

verses.latin: Et respondens David sacerdoti, ait: Equidem si de mulieribus agitur, continuimus nos ab heri et nudiustertius, quando egrediebamur, et fuerunt vasa puerorum sancta. Porro via hæc polluta est, sed et ipsa hodie sanctificabitur in vasis.
verses.english: David answered the high priest, saying, 'Indeed, as for women, we have kept ourselves from them since we began our journey yesterday and the day before. The young men's bodies have been kept ritually pure. Normally, our journey would be defiled, but even our mission will be considered holy today because of the sacred nature of our work, as long as our bodies remain pure.'

verses.latin: Dedit ergo ei sacerdos panem sanctificatum: neque enim erat ibi alius panis, sed tantum panes propositionis, qui sublati fuerant a facie Domini, ut ponerentur panes calidi.
verses.english: So the high priest gave David the holy bread because there was no other bread available there. It was only the showbread, which had been taken from before the Lord's presence in the tabernacle, so that fresh, hot bread could be put in its place.

verses.latin: Erat autem ibi vir de servis Saul, in die illa intus in tabernaculo Domini, nomine Doëg Idumæus, pastor multorum animalium Saul.
verses.english: Now, on that very day, one of Saul's servants was present there inside the tabernacle of the Lord. His name was Doëg the Edomite, and he was the chief over Saul's many herdsmen.

verses.latin: Et ait David ad Achimelech: Si habes hic ad manum hastam vel gladium? quia gladium meum et arma mea non tuli mecum: sermo enim regis urguebat.
verses.english: Then David said to Achimelech, 'Do you have a spear or a sword here that I can take? I didn't bring my own sword or my weapons with me, because the king's mission was too urgent for any delays.'

verses.latin: Et dixit sacerdos: Ecce gladius Goliath Philistæi, quem interfecisti in Valle terebinthi, est involutus pallio post Ephod. Si vis illum tollere, tolle: neque enim est hic alius absque illo. Et ait David: Non est alter similis illi: da mihi eum.
verses.english: The high priest replied, 'Look, the sword of Goliath the Philistine, whom you killed in the Valley of Elah, is here. It is wrapped in a cloth behind the priestly ephod. If you want to take it, then take it, for there is no other sword here. Only that one.' David then exclaimed, 'There is no other sword like it! Give it to me!'

verses.latin: Surrexitque David, et fugit in die illa a facie Saul: et venit ad Achis regem Geth.
verses.english: So David then got up and fled that very day from King Saul's presence. He went to Achish, who was the king of Gath.

verses.latin: Dixerunt autem servi Achis ad eum: Numquid non iste est David rex terræ? nonne huic cantabant in choro, dicentes: Percussit Saul mille, et David decem millia?
verses.english: But the servants of King Achish said to him, 'Is this not David, who is like a king in his own land? Was it not to this very man that they sang in the dances, saying: 'Saul has struck down his thousands, but David his ten thousands?'

verses.latin: Et reposuit David sermones istos in corde suo, et timuit valde a facie Achis regis Geth.
verses.english: David took these words seriously and stored them in his heart, and he became very afraid of King Achish of Gath.

verses.latin: Commutavitque os suum coram eis, et collabebatur inter manus eorum: et impingebat in ostia portæ, et fluebant salivæ ejus in barbam.
verses.english: So David changed his behavior in front of them and feigned madness while they held him. He began to scribble on the city gate doors, and his saliva ran down his beard.

verses.latin: Et ait Achis ad servos suos: Ecce vidistis hominem insanum: quare adduxistis eum ad me?
verses.english: Achish then said to his servants, 'Look, you can see the man is mad! Why have you brought him to me?'

verses.latin: An desunt mihi et insanos, ut adduceretis istum ut fureret me coram? an iste ingredietur domum meam?
verses.english: 'Do I not have enough madmen of my own that you would bring this man here to act like a lunatic in front of me? Should such a man be allowed into my royal residence?'

verses.latin: Fugit ergo David de Geth et venit in speluncam Odollam.
verses.english: So David fled from Gath and came to the cave of Adullam.

verses.latin: David ergo profectus inde salvatus est in spelunca Odollam. Quod cum audissent fratres ejus, et omnis domus patris ejus, descenderunt ad eum illuc.
verses.english: So David fled from Gath and took refuge in the cave of Adullam. When his brothers and all of his father's household heard of his hiding place, they went down to him there.

verses.latin: Et convenerunt ad eum omnes qui erant in angustia constituti, et omni onere gravati, et omni amaritudine animi: et factus est eorum princeps: fueruntque cum eo quasi quadringenti viri.
verses.english: Everyone who was in a difficult situation, burdened by debt, or bitter in spirit gathered to him. And David became their leader. About four hundred men were with him.

verses.latin: Et profectus David inde, abiit in Maspha Moab: et ait ad regem Moab: Maneat, oro, pater meus et mater mea vobiscum, donec sciam quid faciat mihi Deus.
verses.english: From there, David went to Mizpah in Moab. He said to the king of Moab, "Please let my father and my mother stay here with you, until I know what God will do for me" —seeking protection for his parents in his ancestral homeland.

verses.latin: Et reliquit eos apud regem Moab, et manserunt apud eum cunctis diebus quibus David fuit in praesidio.
verses.english: So David left them with the king of Moab, and his parents remained there with the king all the time David was in his places of refuge.

verses.latin: Prophetam autem Gad dixit ad David: Noli manere in praesidio: proficiscere, et vade in terram Juda. Et profectus David venit in silvam Hareth.
verses.english: But the prophet Gad said to David, "Do not remain in this place of refuge. Leave immediately and go into the land of Judah." So David left and went into the forest of Hareth.

verses.latin: Et audivit Saul quod compertus esset David, et viri qui cum eo erant. Saul autem cum maneret in Gabaa, et sedens in luco, qui est in Rama, et lanceam haberet in manu sua, cunctique servi ejus circumstarent eum,
verses.english: Saul heard that David and the men with him had been discovered. At that time, Saul was staying in Gibeah, sitting under a prominent tree in the grove near Ramah, with his spear in his hand, and all his servants were standing around him.

verses.latin: dixit ad servos suos qui circumstabant eum: Audite nunc filii Jemini: numquid omnibus vobis dabit filius Isai agros et vineas, et universos vos faciet tribunos et centuriones,
verses.english: He said to his servants who stood around him, "Listen now, you sons of Benjamin! Will the son of Jesse—David—give all of you fields and vineyards, and make all of you commanders of thousands and commanders of hundreds?"

verses.latin: quoniam conjurastis universi adversum me, et non est qui mihi renuntiet, eo quod filius meus foedus inierit cum filio Isai? Non est qui vicem meam doleat ex vobis, neque qui annuntiet mihi: eo quod suscitaverit filius meus servum meum adversum me insidiantem mihi usque hodie.
verses.english: "You have all conspired against me, and no one informs me that my own son, Jonathan, has made a covenant with the son of Jesse! Is there no one among you who feels for my cause, or who will tell me that my son has stirred up my own servant David against me, inciting him to lie in ambush for me even to this very day?"

verses.latin: Respondens autem Doeg Idumaeus, et unus de servis Saul, qui aderat: Vidi, inquit, filium Isai in Nobe apud Achimelech filium Achitob sacerdotem.
verses.english: But Doeg the Edomite, one of Saul's servants who was standing there, answered, "I saw the son of Jesse—David—in Nob with Ahimelech the priest, son of Ahitub."

verses.latin: Qui consuluit pro eo Dominum, et cibaria dedit ei, sed et gladium Goliath Philisthaei.
verses.english: "Ahimelech consulted the Lord on David's behalf, gave him provisions, and also gave him the sword of Goliath the Philistine."

verses.latin: Misit ergo rex ad Achimelech sacerdotem filium Achitob, et ad omnem domum patris ejus, sacerdotum qui erant in Nobe: qui omnes venerunt ad regem.
verses.english: So the king sent for Ahimelech the priest, son of Ahitub, and for all his father's household—all the priests who were in Nob. They all came to the king.

verses.latin: Et ait Saul: Audi fili Achitob. Qui respondit: Adsum domine mi.
verses.english: And Saul said, "Listen, son of Ahitub." Ahimelech responded, "Here I am, my lord."

verses.latin: Dixitque ad eum Saul: Quare conjurastis adversum me, tu et filius Isai, et dedisti ei panem et gladium, et consulueris pro eo Deum, ut consurgeret adversum me, insidiator usque hodie?
verses.english: Saul then said to him, "Why have you conspired against me, you and the son of Jesse, David? You gave him bread and a sword, and you consulted God on his behalf, so that he might rise up against me as an ambusher even to this very day!"

verses.latin: Respondensque Achimelech regi, ait: Et quis in omnibus servis tuis sicut David, fidelis, et gener regis, et obediens jussioni tuae, et gloriosus in domo tua?
verses.english: Ahimelech responded to the king, saying, "Who among all your servants is as faithful as David? He is also the king's son-in-law, obedient to your command, and held in honor in your own household. He is above reproach."

verses.latin: Numquid hodie cœpi consulere pro eo Dominum? absit hoc a me: ne suspicetur rex in servum suum, nec in omnem domum patris mei. Non enim scivi ego servus tuus quidquam de hoc negotio, vel minus vel majus.
verses.english: "Have I only just today begun to consult the Lord on his behalf? Absolutely not! Let not the king suspect his servant, nor any of my father's household, of any wrongdoing. For I, your servant, knew nothing at all about this matter, neither great nor small."

verses.latin: Dixitque rex: Morte morieris, Achimelech, tu et omnis domus patris tui.
verses.english: Then the king declared, "You will surely die, Ahimelech—you and all of your father's household."

verses.latin: Et ait rex emissariis qui circumstabant eum: Convertimini, et interficite sacerdotes Domini: quia manus eorum cum David est, et scientes quod fugisset, non indicaverunt mihi. Et noluerunt servi regis extendere manum suam, ut irruerent in sacerdotes Domini.
verses.english: Then the king said to the guards who were standing around him, "Turn and kill the priests of the Lord! Their hands are with David, for they knew he had fled but did not inform me." But the king's servants refused to raise their hands to strike down the priests of the Lord.

verses.latin: Et ait rex Doeg: Convertere tu, et irrue in sacerdotes. Et conversus Doeg Idumaeus irruit in sacerdotes, et interfecit in die illa octoginta quinque viros vestitos ephod lineo.
verses.english: Then the king said to Doeg, "You turn and attack the priests!" So Doeg the Edomite turned, attacked the priests, and on that day killed eighty-five men who wore the sacred linen ephod.

verses.latin: Nobe autem civitatem sacerdotum percussit in ore gladii, viros et mulieres, parvulos et lactentes, boves et asinos et oves, in ore gladii.
verses.english: Nob, the city of the priests, was also utterly destroyed by the sword. Doeg put to death men and women, children and infants, oxen, donkeys, and sheep—everything in the city.

verses.latin: Evadens autem unus filius Achimelech filii Achitob, cujus nomen erat Abiathar, fugit ad David.
verses.english: But one son of Ahimelech, son of Ahitub, escaped. His name was Abiathar, and he fled to David.

verses.latin: Et annuntiavit David quod interfecisset Saul sacerdotes Domini.
verses.english: Abiathar informed David that Saul had murdered the priests of the Lord.

verses.latin: Et dixit David ad Abiathar: Sciebam in die illa, quod cum Doeg Idumaeus esset ibi, procul dubio annuntiaret Saul: ego sum reus omnium animarum domus patris tui.
verses.english: David said to Abiathar, "I knew it that day! When Doeg the Edomite was there, I knew he would undoubtedly report everything to Saul. I am responsible for the deaths of everyone in your father's household."

verses.latin: Mane mecum, ne timeas: quicumque enim quaesierit animam meam, quaeret et animam tuam, mecumque servaberis.
verses.english: "Stay with me; do not be afraid. For whoever seeks my life also seeks your life, and you will be safe here with me."

verses.latin: Igitur David recessit inde, et abiit in speluncam Odollam. Quod cum audissent fratres ejus, et omnis domus patris ejus, descenderunt ad eum illuc.
verses.english: David then left that place, and took refuge in the cave of Adullam. When his brothers and his father's entire household heard about this, they went down to join him there.

verses.latin: Et convenerunt ad eum omnes qui erant in angustia, et omni onere gravati, et omni amara anima: et factus est eorum princeps: fueruntque cum eo quasi quadringenti viri.
verses.english: All those who were in distress gathered around him, all who were burdened by any kind of debt or trouble, and all who felt their lives were bitter; and David became their leader. There were about four hundred men with him.

verses.latin: Et profectus David inde, abiit in Maspha, quae est Moab, et dixit ad regem Moab: Maneat, oro, pater meus et mater mea vobiscum, donec sciam quid faciat mihi Deus.
verses.english: From there, David went to Mizpah in Moab, and he said to the king of Moab: "Please allow my father and my mother to stay with you, until I know what God will do for me."

verses.latin: Et reliquit eos apud regem Moab, manseruntque cum eo cunctis diebus quibus David fuit in praesidio.
